Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) CORRECT:

Microscopic examination of this hilar density is most likely to reveal a small cell lung carcinoma. SIADH is one of the common paraneoplastic syndromes associated with SCLC; others include Cushing syndrome and Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are sheets of small cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are present. The stroma appears delicate and scant compared to the sheets of abnormal cells.

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Large cell lung carcinoma is unlikely since it typically has peripheral localization and is not associated with SIADH. In some cases, it may cause paraneoplastic secretion of G-CSF or gynecomastia due to secretion of the beta subunit of β-HCG.

D) INCORRECT:

A bronchial carcinoid tumor is unlikely in this patient because it is not associated with SIADH. Instead, it can cause carcinoid syndrome (due to ectopic serotonin secretion).

E) INCORRECT:

While lung adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer overall, it is associated with hypercoagulability, thrombophlebitis migrans, and nonbacterial verrucous endocarditis rather than SIADH. Additionally, lung adenocarcinoma typically has peripheral localization on imaging, unlike this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.
questions.hint: Hyponatremia in a smoker with weight loss and persistent cough suggests a paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening cough and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows wheezing over the right lung fields. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium concentration of 12.5 mg/dL. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lobar pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus or by anaerobes (due to aspiration) can result in a cavitary lesion due to a lung abscess. However, pneumonia is an acute illness that is associated with a fever and a productive cough, unlike this patient who has had a cough for the past 4 months. Also, pneumonia can cause hyponatremia due to SIADH but it does not cause hypercalcemia.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung abscess

A large thick-walled (green overlay) cavity projecting over the perihilar region of the right lung contains an air-fluid level (indicated by red line).

The differential for this appearance includes abscess (bacterial, mycobacterial, fungal), cavitary noninfectious granuloma, and cavitary malignant lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

A cough and weight loss in an older patient with a long history of smoking raise suspicion for lung cancer. Small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is strongly associated with smoking; however, it typically manifests in the proximal bronchi as a central nodule and does not usually form cavitary lesions. Furthermore, SCLC can cause several paraneoplastic syndromes such as Cushing syndrome, SIADH, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, and paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis but it does not cause hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis can cause a cough, weight loss, and a cavitary lesion on x-ray. Severe pulmonary tuberculosis can also result in hypercalcemia. However, cavitary tuberculous lesions typically form in the superior lobes and are often associated with additional symptoms such as fever and night sweats. In this patient with a 35 pack year smoking history and no history of immunocompromise or tuberculosis exposure, a different diagnosis is much more likely.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

D) INCORRECT:

The constellation of pulmonary symptoms, constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss), and hypercalcemia raises suspicion for sarcoidosis. However, a chest x-ray in a patient with sarcoidosis would show coarse reticular opacities and/or bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. The presence of a solitary cavitary lesion suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with sarcoidosis

The pulmonary hila (green overlay) are enlarged and lobulated. Additionally, the right superior mediastinum (red overlay) is widened and dense. A normal thin right paratracheal stripe is not seen.

Relatively symmetric bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph node enlargement on a chest radiograph in sarcoidosis is termed the “1-2-3 sign” or “Garland triad.” Examples of other causes of hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy include lymphoma, metastatic disease, granulomatous infections, and inorganic dust disease.

E) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung is the most common type of lung cancer that develops in smokers and can cause centrally located cavitary lesions as seen in this case. Although paraneoplastic syndromes are generally more common in patients with small cell lung cancer, certain paraneoplastic syndromes such as humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM) primarily arise in association with SCC. HHM is caused by the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein, which stimulates PTH receptors and thereby increases bone resorption, renal calcium reabsorption, and phosphate excretion, which results in hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma can manifest with weight loss and hypercalcemia. However, this condition would not cause the patient's pulmonary symptoms or x-ray findings. Instead, patients typically present with back pain and fatigue.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.
questions.hint: The x-rays show a heterogeneous, irregularly demarcated lesion with a central cavity and air-fluid level in the right middle lobe. Which respiratory pathology can also cause hypercalcemia?

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with muscle weakness and may rarely be associated with dysautonomia. However, muscle weakness typically is asymmetric and would not improve with exercise, but show a progressive course. Since both upper and lower motor neurons are affected in ALS, additional symptoms such as hyperreflexia, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness would be expected.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica manifests with proximal myopathy, but its main symptoms are myalgia and muscle stiffness rather than weakness. Systemic symptoms, such as weight loss, may be seen in polymyalgia rheumatica, but autonomic dysfunction and hyporeflexia would not be expected. Polymyalgia rheumatica is not associated with lung cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) may cause lower limb muscle weakness. However, symptoms typically worsen throughout the day and with exercise as opposed to this patient's improvement of symptoms upon repetitive stimulation. MG classically manifests with weakness of the extraocular muscles causing ptosis and/or diplopia, whereas deep tendon reflexes and autonomic functions are unaffected. Moreover, MG is not associated with lung cancer, but with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis manifests with proximal muscle weakness. However, symptoms are typically progressive and would not improve with exercise. Although dermatomyositis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer, cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron papules and a heliotrope rash would also be expected. Moreover, dermatomyositis is not associated with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, it would usually be associated with other symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Weight loss as seen in this patient would be unusual. Hypothyroidism is not associated with lung cancer.

F) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody
questions.hint: This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of progressive confusion for the past 2 weeks. He has also had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and fatigue during the last 6 months. Physical examination shows enlarged lymph nodes in the right axilla and faint expiratory wheezing in the right middle lung field. He is only oriented to person. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 125 mEq/L and increased antidiuretic hormone concentration. An x-ray of the chest shows a right-sided hilar mass with mediastinal fullness. A biopsy of the hilar mass is most likely to show cells that stain positive for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Desmin is a muscle-specific intermediate filament found on immunohistochemical staining of muscle tumors such as rhabdomyosarcoma. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which is not a muscle tumor and does not stain positive for desmin.

B) INCORRECT:

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is an enzyme expressed by dendritic cells, macrophages, and osteoclasts that is found on immunohistochemical staining of hairy cell leukemia. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which does not stain positive for TRAP.

C) INCORRECT:

Neurofilament is a neuron-specific intermediate filament found on immunohistochemical staining of neuronal tumors such as neuroblastoma. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which is not a neuronal tumor and does not stain positive for neurofilament.

D) INCORRECT:

Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is a neuroglia-specific intermediate filament found on immunohistochemical staining of glial tumors such as astrocytoma and glioblastoma. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which is not a glial tumor and does not stain positive for GFAP.

E) INCORRECT:

Napsin A is an enzyme found on immunohistochemical staining of several cancers, including lung adenocarcinoma and clear cell endometrial carcinoma. However, it is not expressed by small cell lung cancer. Napsin A staining is used to distinguish lung adenocarcinoma (which typically manifests in the periphery of the lung) from small cell lung cancer (which typically manifests in the central areas of the lung, including the hilar region).

F) INCORRECT:

S-100 is a protein expressed by cells derived from neural crest. Thus, it is found on immunohistochemical staining of tumors derived from these cells, including melanoma, schwannoma, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis. This patient has small cell lung cancer, which does not originate from neural crest cells or stain positive for S-100.

G) INCORRECT:

Vimentin is an intermediate filament that is present in mesenchymal tissue (e.g., cancellous bone, cartilage, muscle, fat, hematopoietic tissues). Thus, it is found on immunohistochemical staining of tumors of mesenchymal origin (sarcomas). Though it is also expressed by several carcinomas (e.g., endometrial carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma), it is not expressed by small cell lung cancer.

H) CORRECT:

Neuron-specific enolase is found on immunohistochemical staining of neuroendocrine tumors such as small cell lung cancer, a neoplasm caused by the proliferation of Kulchitsky cells. Additional immunohistochemical markers for neuroendocrine tumors include chromogranin A and synaptophysin.

Because small cell lung cancer is extremely aggressive and early metastasis is common, surgery is usually not a treatment option. Management typically includes a combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
questions.hint: This patient's hilar mass is caused by small cell lung cancer. This cancer is associated with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), a paraneoplastic syndrome that causes hyponatremia and subsequent confusion.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an episode of coughing with bloody sputum. Over the past 5 months, she has had a persistent nonproductive cough, excessive fatigue, and a 5.6-kg (12.3-lb) weight loss. She does not smoke. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.0-cm nodule with irregular borders at the upper lobe of the left lung. A CT-guided biopsy of the lung nodule is performed. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 15% of all lung cancers. However, small cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral mass that is seen here. In addition, this type of carcinoma is extremely rare in patients who have never smoked.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are sheets of small, dark blue, cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm (enterochromaffin cells).

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Large cell lung carcinoma is usually found in the periphery, as in this case. However, large cell lung carcinoma only accounts for approximately 5–10% of all lung cancers and is therefore not the most likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchial carcinoid tumors are rare, accounting for 1–2% of all lung cancers. In addition, these tumors typically occur in the central airways, not in the periphery as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 20–25% of all lung cancers. While this type of carcinoma is the most common lung cancer among smokers, only 5% of such cases occur in those who have never smoked. In addition, squamous cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral lesion that is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) CORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer and accounts for approximately 40% of all cases. Additionally, as in this patient, adenocarcinoma is more common in women, is usually found in the periphery, and is the most common lung cancer among those who have never smoked.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.
questions.hint: This lung cancer subtype is the most common type of pulmonary malignancy overall.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a cough productive of clear mucoid sputum. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 33 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a 2-cm solid nodule in the periphery of the lower left lobe. A bronchial biopsy of the mass shows numerous mucin-filled epithelial cells lining the alveolar basement membrane. The cells have prominent nucleoli, coarse chromatin, and some cells have multiple nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small cell carcinoma of the lung (SCLC) is an aggressive lung cancer that grows rapidly, metastasizes early, and is usually symptomatic at the time of diagnosis. SCLC typically manifests with a cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, weight loss, paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., SIADH, Lambert-Eaton syndrome), and/or symptomatic distant metastases. Smoking is an important risk factor for SCLC, which would typically appear as a central hilar mass on x-ray, unlike this patient's peripheral nodule. Biopsy would show numerous small cells with scanty cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei (Kulchitsky cells), mitoses, necrosis, and extensive local infiltration – not mucin-filled epithelial cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are sheets of small cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are present. The stroma appears delicate and scant compared to the sheets of abnormal cells.

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary hamartoma is the most common benign tumor of the lung and is composed of hyaline cartilage, fat, and smooth muscle. It is most common in men > 50 years of age, is usually asymptomatic but can cause a chronic cough, and is typically seen as a solitary peripheral pulmonary nodule. However, a biopsy would show hyaline cartilage, areas of ossification, and entrapped islands of normal alveolar epithelial cells, in contrast to this patient's biopsy findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen taken from a pulmonary nodule (H&E stain, low magnification).

On the right side, normal lung tissue (green overlay) with air-filled spaces (parts of small airways, alveoli) can be seen. On the left side, condensed tissue appears with a mixture of pale-staining immature myxomatous tissue (examples indicated by blue overlay), connective and fat tissue (identifiable as large unstained lipid vacuoles; examples indicated by arrowheads), and multiple clefts lined by dark-staining epithelium (examples indicated by yellow lines).
Often hyaline cartilage can also be found in such pulmonary nodules (not present here).

In the absence of any signs of malignancy (e.g., cellular atypia, mitosis, necrosis), this abnormal mixture of multiple tissue components in the lung indicates pulmonary hamartoma (the most common type of benign lung tumor).

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis is an interstitial lung disease that typically manifests with cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and fatigue. Although a nonspecific cough with no auscultatory abnormalities may be seen in pure pulmonary sarcoidosis, the chest x-ray would classically show bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. A solitary pulmonary nodule, as seen in this patient's x-ray, is not a feature of pulmonary sarcoidosis. In addition, an endobronchial biopsy in sarcoidosis would typically show noncaseating granulomas.

D) CORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma in situ of the lung is defined as a pulmonary nodule that is ≤ 3 cm in diameter and composed of tumor cells that line the alveolar basement membrane without invading it or adjacent neurovascular tissue (i.e., lepidic growth pattern). Most patients with lung adenocarcinoma are either asymptomatic or, like this patient, present with a cough productive of mucoid sputum. Smoking is a risk factor for all lung cancers. This patient's history of chronic smoking, mucoid cough, 2-cm pulmonary nodule, and the non-invasive tumor on histology make the diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma most likely.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of primary lung cancer overall. It is also the most common type in women and in non-smokers.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.

E) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid tumor of the lung is a rare pulmonary neuroendocrine tumor that predominantly arises in the main bronchi. Carcinoid tumor may manifest with a nonspecific cough and be seen as a solitary hilar mass on chest x-ray, as in this patient. A biopsy of a carcinoid tumor would show numerous polygonal cells arranged in either nests, rosettes, or trabeculae. The cells would have peripherally palisading nuclei with fine chromatin (salt and pepper chromatin) and small nucleoli, which is not consistent with this patient's biopsy findings. Immunohistochemistry is required to definitively diagnose a carcinoid tumor.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (chromogranin A immunostain)

The cells show positive cytoplasmic staining for chromogranin.

Lung tissue normally does not stain positive for chromogranin. This finding indicates a neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumor.

F) INCORRECT:

Endobronchial tuberculosis is an infection of the tracheobronchial tree caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which can manifest as a nonspecific cough. In patients with endobronchial tuberculosis, the chest x-ray may be normal or include findings of parenchymal consolidation or infiltration and/or hilar lymphadenopathy. A biopsy would show caseating granulomas, in contrast to this patient's biopsy findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of pulmonary tissue (H&E stain)

There is a circular pattern of purple-stained immune cells in the center of the image. These immune cells enclose a large collection of necrotic pulmonary tissue (stained in red). In the periphery, other smaller caseating granulomas can be seen.

The formation of caseating granulomas (also called pulmonary cavitation) is typical of pulmonary tuberculosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: This condition is associated with the occurrence of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination one week after a chest x-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule. He has no history of major medical illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test is negative. A CT scan of the chest shows a 2.1-cm well-circumscribed, calcified nodule in the periphery of the right lower lung field. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is performed. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen shows regions of disorganized hyaline cartilage interspersed with myxoid regions and clefts of ciliated epithelium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pulmonary hamartoma (PH) is the most common cause of a benign solitary pulmonary nodule. This diagnosis is further supported by the tumor size (PH are typically 1–3 cm in diameter), the benign appearance on imaging (round, well-circumscribed, calcified mass; 90% of PH are in peripheral lung areas), and the histology findings (typical features of PH include cartilage lobules that calcify or undergo osseous changes and fibromyxoid tissue with clefts of ciliated epithelium). PHs are usually asymptomatic and only occasionally cause symptoms by obstructing a bronchus (e.g., atelectasis, pneumonitis, cough, expectoration, chest pain).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen taken from a pulmonary nodule (H&E stain, low magnification).

On the right side, normal lung tissue (green overlay) with air-filled spaces (parts of small airways, alveoli) can be seen. On the left side, condensed tissue appears with a mixture of pale-staining immature myxomatous tissue (examples indicated by blue overlay), connective and fat tissue (identifiable as large unstained lipid vacuoles; examples indicated by arrowheads), and multiple clefts lined by dark-staining epithelium (examples indicated by yellow lines).
Often hyaline cartilage can also be found in such pulmonary nodules (not present here).

In the absence of any signs of malignancy (e.g., cellular atypia, mitosis, necrosis), this abnormal mixture of multiple tissue components in the lung indicates pulmonary hamartoma (the most common type of benign lung tumor).

B) INCORRECT:

Cartilaginous choristomas consist of cartilage tissue, which histological examination revealed also in this patient's pulmonary nodule. However, choristomas are rarely found in the lung and more typically develop in the external auditory canal and the oral cavity.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy from an intraoral mass (H&E stain)

Bundles of skeletal muscle are identifiable as parallel fibers, some with striations (longitudinal sections of skeletal muscle) and groups of polygonal multinucleated cells with peripheral nuclei arranged in a mosaic pattern (transverse sections of skeletal muscle).
Clusters of mucinous glands composed of pale staining cells with basal nuclei around a central duct are also visible.
Adipose tissue is visible in the top left corner as unstained vacuoles with a cytoplasmic rim and a peripheral nucleus.

This appearance of histologically normal tissue in an abnormal location is characteristic of a choristoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomas are often incidental findings diagnosed on chest x-ray for another indication. In 25% of the cases, patients with eosinophilic granulomas are asymptomatic, as this patient is, or have nonspecific symptoms. Moreover, cigarette smoke increases the risk of developing eosinophilic granulomas. However, solitary eosinophilic granulomas usually manifest as multiple diffuse micronodules and only rarely develop as solitary pulmonary nodules. Additionally, histological examination of an eosinophilic granuloma would show large cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and lobed nuclei and an inflammatory infiltrate; but no cartilage cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy sample from a pulmonary nodule (H&E stain; high magnification)

Numerous specialized histiocytes (Langerhans cells; examples indicated by arrowheads) are identifiable as large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and large folded or grooved nuclei (coffee bean nuclei; zoom box). A mixed inflammatory infiltrate of eosinophils (yellow overlay), neutrophils, and lymphocytes is also visible.

The presence of Langerhans cells was confirmed by immunohistochemistry (Langerin, CD1a, and S100 positive).

D) INCORRECT:

A mature teratoma is a differential diagnosis to consider in patients with a solitary pulmonary nodule. Mature teratomas typically manifest as solid lesions that often contain calcified tissue and cartilage on histological examination, which are also seen in this patient. However, mature teratomas typically arise in the gonads or the sacrococcygeal region. In the rare case that a teratoma forms in the lung, it would most likely do so in the upper lung field and cause cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and hair expectoration, none of which is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of ovary tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

On the left is an area of dark-pink-stained bone matrix with embedded osteocytes and osteoblasts in the periphery of the aggregation. Various purple-stained hair follicles can be seen from the center to the bottom of the image.

These findings are consistent with a mature teratoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

SCLC is a highly malignant type of cancer and an important differential diagnosis of a solitary pulmonary nodule. This patient's smoking history puts him at increased risk for developing a malignant lung disease. However, SCLC is typically found in the perihilar region. Moreover, typical histological findings on H&E stain would include small dark blue cells (enterochromaffin cells), but not cartilage cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of small cell lung cancer (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

Sheets of small round cells with scanty cytoplasm and deep blue nuclei are visible throughout the image. The stroma (pink hypocellular tissue) is scanty.

This is the typical appearance of small cell lung cancer at high magnification.

F) INCORRECT:

A bronchogenic cyst is an important differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule. Bronchogenic cysts often present without any symptoms and can show calcification on CT scan, which is also seen in this patient. Histological examination may also show findings of cartilage and epithelium. However, further CT findings would show cystic features like a fluid or air-filled cavity, which are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a mediastinal cyst cross-section specimen (H&E stain; 450x magnification)

The lumen is lined by ciliated epithelium (green overlay; examples of cilia indicated by arrowheads) and layers of smooth muscle (yellow overlay) are visible, resembling upper airway tissue. Also, normal adipose tissue (examples of adipocytes indicated by black dashed outlines) can be found in the periphery.

The typical location (suprasternal, behind the manubrium, middle mediastinum) paired with the described histologic appearance indicates a bronchogenic cyst.
questions.hint: The findings in this patient result from the most common cause of benign solitary pulmonary nodules.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of upper extremity weakness and fatigue for the past 4 months. She has had difficulty combing her hair and lifting objects. She has also had difficulty rising from her bed in the mornings for 2 months. Over the past month, she started using over-the-counter mouth rinses for dry mouth. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows decreased deep tendon reflexes. Repetitive muscle tapping shows increased reflex activity. There are no fasciculations or muscle atrophy. A low-dose CT scan of the chest shows a 3-cm mass with heterogeneous calcifications in the center of the right lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CNS is one of the most common locations for lung cancer metastasis, which can present with focal neurological deficits. Patients with brain metastasis may exhibit muscle weakness, as seen here. However, upper motor neuron symptoms (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) would also be expected, rather than the decreased deep tendon reflexes observed in this patient. In addition, brain metastasis commonly presents with headaches, cognitive deficits, and seizures, none of which are present here. Moreover, her autonomic symptom (dry mouth) and the increased reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory myopathies (IM), such as polymyositis and dermatomyositis, typically manifest with proximal muscle weakness, as seen in this patient. However, her autonomic symptom (dry mouth) and the decreased deep tendon reflexes with improvement after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with IM. Although a strong association exists between dermatomyositis and malignancy, this patient lacks the typical cutaneous manifestations of this disease (i.e., Gottron papules, heliotrope rash), which excludes dermatomyositis as the underlying mechanism responsible for her presentation.

C) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic autoimmune disease, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer. In LEMS, antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels impair acetylcholine (ACh) release in the neuromuscular junction. This leads to proximal muscle weakness, autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation), and decreased deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient. A unique feature of LEMS is an improvement in strength and reflex activity with repeated use/stimulation. Since postsynaptic ACh receptors remain intact in LEMS, once enough ACh has built up in the postsynaptic cleft from repeated stimulation, muscle contraction can return.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

D) INCORRECT:

Hereditary causes of muscle weakness include muscular dystrophies (e.g., Duchenne muscular dystrophy), hereditary motor sensory neuropathies (HMSN) (e.g., Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease), and congenital myopathies. Although decreased deep tendon reflexes, as seen here, may be found in all of these conditions, increased reflex activity after repeated stimulation would not be present. Moreover, further symptoms such as muscle atrophy and, in the case of HMSN, sensory deficits would be expected. Finally, these hereditary conditions almost exclusively manifest in childhood or early adulthood.

E) INCORRECT:

Invasion of a lung carcinoma into the cervical sympathetic chain can lead to Pancoast syndrome, presenting with upper extremity weakness and loss of deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient. However, muscle weakness in Pancoast syndrome is typically unilateral. In addition, further symptoms caused by the compression or infiltration of local structures by the tumor would be expected (e.g., shoulder pain, muscle atrophy, sensory deficits, Horner syndrome, hoarseness, and superior vena cava syndrome). An increase in reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation is inconsistent with this diagnosis. Moreover, the patient's CT revealed a mass in the center of the right lung, whereas Pancoast tumors are always located in the superior sulcus.

F) INCORRECT:

Some viral infections that affect the anterior horn cells can cause muscle weakness, resulting in flaccid paralysis or invasion of the muscle itself (i.e., myositis). Viruses that cause flaccid paralysis include poliovirus, nonpolio enteroviruses, and West Nile virus, all of which are extremely unlikely in a patient without a travel history to endemic areas. Moreover, further symptoms such as muscle fasciculations, atrophy, and signs of infection (e.g., fever, malaise, headache) would be expected. Viral myositis is commonly caused by influenza viruses and enteroviruses; patients typically present with fever, myalgia, and a history of an upper respiratory tract infection, none of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, her slowly progressive symptoms, autonomic symptom (dry mouth), and the increased reflex activity noted after repeated stimulation are inconsistent with an infectious cause.
questions.hint: A CT scan showing a 3-cm pulmonary mass with irregular calcifications in a patient with a 40 pack-year history of cigarette smoking is suspicious for lung malignancy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and a worsening cough for the past month. He also reports occasional bloody sputum. He has lost about 7 kg (15.4 lb) of weight over the past 6 months despite having no change in appetite. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years but stopped smoking at the age of 55. Physical examination shows reduced breath sounds throughout both lungs. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell lung carcinoma can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, this type of primary lung cancer is strongly associated with smoking. However, a chest x-ray would typically show a hilar mass and cavitation rather than the multiple, bilateral lesions seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, this type of primary lung cancer is strongly associated with smoking. However, a chest x-ray would typically show a single central nodule rather than the multiple, bilateral lesions seen here. In addition, SCLC is commonly accompanied by paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, Cushing syndrome), which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

Lung adenocarcinoma, which is the most common type of primary lung cancer, can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. However, a chest x-ray would typically show a single peripheral nodule rather than the multiple, bilateral lesions seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A solitary nodule (red overlay) with an irregular margin is visible in the periphery of the upper left lung. An additional soft-tissue opacity peripheral to the nodule along the ribs may represent adjacent pleural thickening (green overlay).

The differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule includes neoplastic (malignant and benign), inflammatory, and congenital conditions.

D) CORRECT:

Round nodules of varying sizes scattered throughout the lungs (“cannonball lesions”) suggest pulmonary metastases. Moreover, this patient reports that systemic symptoms (i.e., weight loss) preceded the onset of pulmonary symptoms (dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis) by several months, which should raise suspicion for a primary extrathoracic malignancy. Lung metastases occur in up to 50% of cancer patients, with breast, colorectal, and renal carcinomas among the most common primary tumors in adults. An extensive diagnostic workup (e.g., imaging, biopsy with histology and immunohistochemistry) should be initiated to identify this patient's primary malignancy.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with lung metastases from colon carcinoma

Multiple small, circumscribed nodules of varying sizes (examples indicated by green overlays) can be seen in both lungs. A few nodules (examples indicated by red overlays) contain small foci of air, which may represent small bronchioles or sites of early cavitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Pleural mesothelioma can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, and weight loss, all of which are seen in this patient. However, this type of malignancy almost exclusively occurs due to inhalational asbestos exposure, which this patient has not reported. Moreover, a chest x-ray would typically show pleural plaques and/or calcifications and unilateral pleural effusion rather than the multiple pulmonary lesions seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with mesothelioma

A rounded opacity (green overlay) superior to the right hilum has a circumscribed inferior margin and an ill-defined superior margin (incomplete border sign). Similar smaller partially circumscribed opacities (examples indicated by red overlay) project over several ribs in the mid-right hemithorax. The presence of an incomplete border sign helps distinguish extrapulmonary (pleural or chest wall) masses from lung masses on a chest radiograph. An Implantable cardiac defibrillator (ICD)-pacemaker is also seen.
questions.hint: The patient's chest x-ray shows numerous round, well-circumscribed pulmonary lesions.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six weeks ago, he was admitted to the hospital for a pulmonary abscess in the periphery of the left lower lobe of the lung and underwent transthoracic tube drainage. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. A chest x-ray shows an opacification in the periphery of the left lower lobe as a result of residual scar tissue. The patient is concerned about possible long term complications from the lung scar. This patient is at greatest risk for developing a pulmonary malignancy comprised of which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anaplastic small-blue-round cells are characteristic of small cell carcinoma, which can develop in a lung scar but this tumor is not the most common histologic type of lung scar carcinoma. Moreover, small cell lung cancer typically has a central location in the lung and is strongly associated with smoking.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are sheets of small, dark blue, cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm (enterochromaffin cells).

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Serotonergic neuroendocrine cells are characteristic of bronchial carcinoid, a rare low-grade malignancy that is more commonly located centrally than peripherally. This tumor is not clearly associated with any known carcinogen and is not associated with pulmonary scar tissue. A different type of lung cancer would be expected to develop in a pulmonary scar.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Multiple nests of small, round, monomorphic cells can be seen throughout the tissue (green hatched overlay). Some of these cells are arranged in rosette formations (green overlay). The chromatin is finely grained in the monomorphic cells (known as "salt-and-pepper chromatin"). Hyperemic capillaries between the cell nests indicate rich vascularization (examples indicated by green arrowheads).

These findings are consistent with a neuroendocrine tumor.

C) INCORRECT:

Nests of squamous tumor cells (forming keratin pearls) are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), which can develop in a lung scar but this tumor is not the most common histologic type of lung scar carcinoma. Moreover, squamous cell lung cancer is typically located in the central airways and is very strongly associated with smoking (> 95% of SCCs occur in smokers).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E staining; high magnification)

There are several nests (example indicated by yellow overlay) composed of large, polygonal, atypical squamous cells with polymorphic nuclei, intercellular bridges (examples indicated by arrowheads) and evidence of keratinization (examples indicated by blue circles).

These are the classic features of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with keratinization. In lung tissue, the presence of SCC can represent primary SCC of the lung or metastasis of an extrapulmonary SCC (more common). Therefore, initial diagnosis in biopsy material requires clinical exclusion of a primary extrapulmonary SCC (e.g., pharyngolaryngeal or anogenital).

D) CORRECT:

Mucin-producing glandular tumor cells are characteristic of adenocarcinoma, which accounts for 60–70% of lung cancers that originate from a scar. Lung scar carcinoma (LSC) tends to be peripheral in location, as does adenocarcinoma of the lung. Scarring from tuberculosis is the most common risk factor for LSC. Other known causes of lung scars from which lung cancer has developed include pulmonary abscess (as seen here), bronchiectasis, pneumonia, pulmonary fibrosis, and pulmonary infarction. A chronic inflammatory response to a lung scar can lead to persistent DNA damage and oncogene activation, resulting in neoplastic transformation. LSC metastasizes early and has a worse prognosis than lung carcinoma not associated with scars.

There are currently no guidelines on screening patients with lung scars for the development of lung cancer. Without sequential images for comparison, lung scar carcinoma may be misdiagnosed on CT as a fibrotic lesion.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Adjacent to normal lung tissue at the bottom of the image (dashed line) several nests of abnormal, pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen. Some of the nests form central lumina that contain necrotic debris (examples indicated by blue overlay).

These findings suggest adenocarcinoma of the lung. However, a metastasis of adenocarcinoma of another origin (e.g. colon) must be ruled out by immunohistochemistry.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphic giant cells are seen in large cell carcinoma, which typically has a peripheral location in the lung and can develop from scar tissue in the lung. However, this tumor is not the most common histologic type of lung scar carcinoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (PAS stain)

Numerous enlarged cells with multiple nuclei.

This appearance is suggestive of large-cell lung carcinoma. However, immunohistochemical analysis of the cells is needed for a definite diagnosis.
questions.hint: The kind of pulmonary malignancy that is most likely to develop from lung scar tissue is also the most common type of lung cancer in the general population and among nonsmokers.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of increasing pain, swelling, and stiffness in both ankles. The pain and stiffness worsen with movement. She has no history of serious illnesses and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 36.8ºC (98.2ºF). Physical examination shows digital clubbing. The ankle joints are swollen and tender to palpation; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the lower extremities shows periosteal thickening of the distal tibial diaphysis in both extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (HOA) is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma of the lung. Patients with HOA present with arthritis, digital clubbing, and periostitis of the distal diaphysis of long bones, as seen here. Some affected individuals also develop thickening of the skin (pachyderma). The exact pathophysiology of this condition is not entirely understood but the release of certain growth factors like VEGF and PDGF from the tumor is thought to play a role. Other causes include chronic pulmonary conditions (e.g., bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis) and, less commonly, hepatic and gastrointestinal disease (e.g., cirrhosis, inflammatory bowel disease). HOA in a previously healthy patient should raise suspicion for occult pulmonary malignancy and a low-dose CT scan of the chest should be obtained. Adenocarcinoma of the lung can occur in nonsmokers, like this patient, and is more common among female than male individuals.

In rare cases, HOA occurs as a result of a hereditary disorder (primary HOA).
Image Description:

X-ray ankle (left: AP view; right: lateral view)

Smooth periosteal reaction (green overlay) has developed primarily along the distal metaphyses of the tibia and fibula.

This appearance is characteristic of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Accelerated bone turnover is the cause of Paget disease of bone (PDB), which often affects the long bones of the lower extremities (e.g., tibia). PDB can manifest with bone pain, swelling overlying the affected region, and periosteal thickening. However, PDB typically does not lead to arthritis, and in addition to a periosteal reaction, an x-ray would show lytic and/or sclerotic lesions in the bone cortex and, possibly, anterior bowing of the tibia. This patient's condition is not the result of accelerated bone turnover.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis

Enlargement of the right hemipelvis is accompanied by coarsened trabeculation and areas of sclerosis compatible with abnormal remodeling in Paget disease (green overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

A right-to-left cardiac or pulmonary shunt (e.g., pulmonary arteriovenous malformation) rather than a left-to-right cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale) can cause hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. A right-to-left shunt bypasses the filtering effect of pulmonary circulation on platelet clumps, which then accumulate peripherally and produce growth factors (e.g., PDGF) that can cause osseous hypertrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency can cause bone pain but does not cause joint swelling and stiffness or digital clubbing. Moreover, x-ray findings of osteomalacia include decreased bone lucency and Looser zones, not periosteal thickening. This patient's condition is not the result of a nutritional deficiency.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right leg and ankle joint of an elderly patient (AP view)

Multiple transverse, radiolucent lines with sclerotic margins (example indicated by white arrow) can be seen extending into the bone from the cortical surface of the tibia and fibula. Diffuse demineralization (osteopenia) of the tibia and fibula is evidenced by their radiolucent appearance and the bowing of the fibular shaft.

The radiolucent lines are pseudofractures, known as Looser zones, which are typically seen in patients with osteomalacia and rickets.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune joint disease that occasionally affects the ankle joints, and manifests with joint pain, swelling, and decreased range of motion. However, the stiffness and pain associated with RA typically improve rather than worsen with activity. Moreover, RA does not cause digital clubbing or periosteal thickening; instead, finger deformities (e.g., swan neck deformity, Boutonniere deformity) and different x-ray findings (e.g., concentric joint space narrowing, subcortical cysts, para-articular osteopenia) would be expected. This patient's arthralgia is not the result of an autoimmune process.
Image Description:

X-ray hands (PA view)

There is generalized periarticular osteopenia (example indicated by green overlay) and narrowing of several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joint spaces (example indicated by green line). The marked deformity of the wrists is the result of numerous carpal, base of metacarpal, and radiocarpal erosions (red lines). Erosive scalloping (example indicated by yellow line) also involves the radioulnar joint.

The radiographic findings are typical of rheumatoid arthritis with advanced wrist involvement.

F) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis is a chronic degenerative disease that can affect the ankle joints and manifests with joint stiffness, restricted range of motion, and pain that worsens with activity. However, osteoarthritis does not cause digital clubbing or periosteal thickening. Instead, an x-ray would show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and/or subchondral cysts. This patient's condition is not the result of a chronic degenerative process.
Image Description:

X-ray anterior foot (bilateral; AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes can be seen at the left first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint and sesamoid articulations (indicated by red lines), with prominent MTP joint osteophytes (yellow overlay), subchondral sclerosis (green overlay), and joint space narrowing (blue line). There is lesser involvement of the right first MTP joint. No articular erosions can be seen.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, which is due to distal hyperemia and proliferation of connective tissue in the distal parts of extremities, especially the fingers.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent, sharp pain in the left shoulder that radiates to his neck. During this time, he has also had difficulty lifting heavy objects with his left arm. He has not had any recent trauma. He has noticed uneven sweating, with less sweat on the left side of his face. He has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight loss during the past 3 months despite no change in appetite or level of activity. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, aspirin, and atorvastatin. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not drink alcoholic beverages or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. When measured in dim light, the left pupil measures 3 mm and the right pupil 5 mm in diameter. There is drooping of the left eyelid. Muscle strength is 3/5 on abduction and flexion of the left shoulder. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wallenberg syndrome, which is most commonly caused by posterior inferior cerebellar artery or vertebral artery occlusion (due to atherosclerosis), can manifest with Horner syndrome. In addition, this patient's history of smoking and hypertension increases his risk of developing cerebrovascular syndromes. However, Wallenberg syndrome does not manifest with shoulder pain and weight loss; expected findings include dysphagia, dysphonia, decreased gag reflex, ataxia, and nystagmus.

B) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) may manifest with weight loss and shoulder pain. In addition, in 20% of cases, PMR is associated with giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can occasionally result in ptosis (due to an isolated oculomotor nerve palsy). However, the pain seen in PMR is typically symmetrical and patients usually have muscle stiffness, especially in the morning. Moreover, patients with GCA and an oculomotor nerve palsy present with a dilated or normal-sized pupil, not miosis. Finally, patients with GCA typically have additional clinical features such as headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and/or loss of vision.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of weight loss, unilateral shoulder pain and decreased functionality, and Horner syndrome in this elderly patient with a history of heavy smoking suggests a Pancoast tumor, an apical lung carcinoma (usually a type of NSCLC such as bronchogenic adenocarcinoma) that involves the superior sulcus of the lungs. Most symptoms of a Pancoast tumor are attributed to the compression of the surrounding structures: compression of the brachial plexus causes shoulder pain, while compression of the cervical sympathetic nerves by the tumor results in Horner syndrome. The next step in management should be a CT scan of the chest to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the tumor in order to plan further diagnostic steps (e.g., biopsy) and treatment.

Other possible findings of Pancoast tumor include hoarseness (due to laryngeal nerve compression) and unilateral arm edema (due to brachiocephalic vein obstruction).
Image Description:

Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

D) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery dissection may manifest with unilateral miosis, ptosis, and neck pain. In addition, this patient's history of smoking and hypertension increases his risk of developing this condition. However, carotid artery dissection does not explain the anhidrosis, since the sympathetic fibers of the facial sweat glands are located on the external carotid artery. Moreover, this patient does not present with ischemic features (e.g., amaurosis fugax, findings of middle cerebral artery infarction), which are typically seen in this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Angle-closure glaucoma can manifest with mydriasis, leading to anisocoria. However, the affected eye is usually reddened and severely painful, and most patients experience headache and/or orbital pain. In addition, angle-closure glaucoma does not manifest with anhidrosis, ptosis, shoulder pain, and weight loss.

F) INCORRECT:

Neurosyphilis may cause miosis. However, miosis in neurosyphilis is typically bilateral. In addition, patients with neurosyphilis usually present with Argyll Robertson pupils: the pupils accommodate but do not react to direct or indirect light. Furthermore, neurosyphilis does not usually manifest with anhidrosis, ptosis, and shoulder pain.

G) INCORRECT:

One of the first symptoms to develop in myasthenia gravis (MG) is ptosis. However, MG typically causes weakness (predominantly of the proximal muscle groups) that worsens with exercise and improves with rest rather than shoulder pain. Furthermore, anhidrosis and anisocoria are not expected findings.
questions.hint: This patient's unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis are consistent with Horner syndrome.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the office to establish care after moving to the area from a different state with her husband and 3 children. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and constipation. Her current medication includes valsartan, salmeterol, and a fiber supplement for constipation. She entered menopause last year. Four years ago, she underwent hemorrhoidectomy; a sigmoidoscopy at that time showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 66 years; the patient's last mammogram from 6 months ago was normal. Her last primary HPV test taken 3 years ago was negative. She does not drink alcohol. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 8 years ago when she was diagnosed with COPD. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows varicose veins in the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable for her age. Which of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is indicated for lung cancer screening in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a smoking history ≥ 20 pack years. Screening recommendations for former smokers vary. Although the American Cancer Society supports screening regardless of time since last smoked, some organizations (e.g., USPSTF) recommend limiting screening to individuals who have smoked within the past 15 years.

See “Screening for cancer” and “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” tables.

B) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Sigmoidoscopy every 5 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last sigmoidoscopy 4 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), sigmoidoscopy is not indicated at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Mammography is indicated for the screening of breast cancer in women aged 40–74 years. According to the latest 2024 USPSTF recommendation, mammography should be repeated every 2 years. This patient had a mammogram 6 months ago with normal findings and does not require any further testing right now.

D) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF recommendation, Pap smear is indicated for the screening of cervical cancer in women aged 21 to 65 years. Pap smear should be performed every 3 years if done alone, or every 5 years when performed as co-testing. Alternatively, in patients aged 30 to 65 years, the FDA-approved primary HPV tests performed every 5 years are sufficient for cervical cancer screening. This patient had HPV testing 3 years ago and does not require any further testing at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography is used to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and is recommended in men 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history. Screening can also be considered in women 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history, in individuals < 65 years of age with multiple risk factors for AAA and/or a family history of AAA, and in individuals 65–75 years of age with a positive family history for AAA in a first-degree relative. Based on this patient's sex, age, and risk factors, screening for a different condition with another modality is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This screening study is recommended by the United States Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF) in adults aged 50 to 80 years.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of persistent cough and shortness of breath. Over the past 5 months, he has had recurrent episodes of pneumonia treated with antibiotics without full recovery. He does not have a history of serious illness. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs discloses expiratory wheezing over the right lung; there is dullness to percussion over the right lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows a pulmonary nodule in the central portion of the right middle lung field and collapse of the right middle lobe against the mediastinum. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest shows that the nodule is 22-mm in diameter, contrast-enhancing, and solid with well-defined, smooth borders. A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained via transbronchial biopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
Large cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, recurrent pneumonia or atelectasis, and a central lesion on chest x-ray. However, SCC of the lung typically occurs in smokers and chest imaging would usually show cavitary rather than a solid nodule. In addition, SCC is characterized by keratinization and intercellular bridges on biopsy, unlike this patient's biopsy findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E staining; high magnification)

There are several nests (example indicated by yellow overlay) composed of large, polygonal, atypical squamous cells with polymorphic nuclei, intercellular bridges (examples indicated by arrowheads) and evidence of keratinization (examples indicated by blue circles).

These are the classic features of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with keratinization. In lung tissue, the presence of SCC can represent primary SCC of the lung or metastasis of an extrapulmonary SCC (more common). Therefore, initial diagnosis in biopsy material requires clinical exclusion of a primary extrapulmonary SCC (e.g., pharyngolaryngeal or anogenital).

B) INCORRECT:

Large cell carcinoma (LCC) of the lung can manifest with progressive dyspnea and cough. LCC of the lung most commonly occurs in smokers and is usually located in a peripheral lung field, unlike this patient's central nodule. A biopsy of an LCC sample from the lung shows large, anaplastic cells with no evidence of neuroendocrine differentiation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200× magnification; scale bar: 100 μm; 400× magnification; scale bar: 50 μm)

A tumor composed of multiple, round cell nests (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen. The tumor cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) have abundant pale eosinophilic cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. There is no evidence of keratinization or glandular or neuroendocrine differentiation.

Immunohistochemical stains (negative for TTF-1, p63, and neuroendocrine markers, and positive for cytokeratins) confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lung metastases are the most common lung tumors, manifest with progressive dyspnea and cough, and can be the initial presentation of an occult extrapulmonary tumor. However, lung metastases most commonly appear as multiple round nodules of varying sizes on chest imaging rather than a single nodule. Moreover, this patient's biopsy findings are consistent with a primary neuroendocrine tumor of the lung.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with lung metastases from colon carcinoma

Multiple small, circumscribed nodules of varying sizes (examples indicated by green overlays) can be seen in both lungs. A few nodules (examples indicated by red overlays) contain small foci of air, which may represent small bronchioles or sites of early cavitation.

D) CORRECT:

Bronchial carcinoid tumors account for 1–2% of all lung cancers but are the most common primary lung cancer in children and adolescents. Patients with this condition can present with progressive dyspnea, cough, and recurrent pneumonia or atelectasis in the same pulmonary segment as a result of bronchial obstruction, as seen here. In comparison to patients with gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors, these patients rarely develop carcinoid syndrome because bronchial carcinoid tumors produce less serotonin. Imaging of the chest typically shows a round, smooth, well-defined, vascular (contrast-enhancing) tumor that is located near the bronchus (often with an endobronchial component) of a central or peripheral lung field. Depending on clinical staging, surgical resection or radiation therapy is indicated. Unlike lung squamous cell carcinoma and small cell lung cancer, bronchial carcinoid tumor is not associated with smoking. Bronchial carcinoid tumors rarely metastasize and with treatment, the prognosis is good.

E) INCORRECT:

Lung adenocarcinoma, which is the most common type of primary lung cancer (40–50% of cases), often occurs in nonsmokers and can manifest with progressive dyspnea and cough. However, chest imaging typically shows a peripheral nodule rather than a central lesion, and biopsy characteristically shows mucin-producing glandular tumor cells, unlike this patient's biopsy findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Adjacent to normal lung tissue at the bottom of the image (dashed line) several nests of abnormal, pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen. Some of the nests form central lumina that contain necrotic debris (examples indicated by blue overlay).

These findings suggest adenocarcinoma of the lung. However, a metastasis of adenocarcinoma of another origin (e.g. colon) must be ruled out by immunohistochemistry.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: The biopsy shows multiple nests of small, round, monomorphic cells (Kulchitsky cells), some of which are arranged in a rosette formation separated by connective tissue, which is typical for this patient's condition. Further immunostaining with chromogranin A is most likely to establish the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of an incidentally detected pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray. She feels well. Medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease controlled with tiotropium bromide. Her father received the diagnosis of lung cancer at the age of 66 years. She has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 32 years. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air discloses an oxygen saturation of 94%. CT scan of the chest shows a nodule in the right lung. Which of the following radiographic findings is the strongest predictor for malignancy in this patient's pulmonary mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nodule location is a criterion used to assess the risk of malignancy in patients with solitary pulmonary nodules; however, location in the lower lobe is associated with a low risk of malignancy. Upper lobe location is a high-risk feature.

B) INCORRECT:

Nodule size is a criterion used to assess the risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules. A nodule < 8 mm in size is associated with an intermediate or low risk of malignancy, whereas nodule size > 8–10 mm is considered a high-risk feature.

C) INCORRECT:

Although cavitation can be seen in cavitating lung metastasis, this feature is not specific and therefore not used in the assessment of the risk of malignancy. Inflammatory lung conditions such as lung abscess, sarcoidosis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis can also manifest with cavitation. A different finding is a stronger predictor for malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcification can be seen in some lung cancers, such as pulmonary carcinoid tumors. However, this feature is generally associated with benign conditions such as benign pulmonary hamartomas, which are characterized by popcorn calcifications with alterations of fat. Calcifications can also be seen in tuberculosis or Histoplasma capsulatum-induced infectious granulomas.

E) CORRECT:

The risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules can be determined by clinical evaluation and/or predictive modeling and helps guide management and follow-up. Pulmonary nodules with irregular borders (e.g., scalloped, spiculated) arise due to tumor growth along the pulmonary interstitium and carry a high risk of malignancy. Additional features that indicate a high risk of malignancy include upper lobe location and large nodule size (e.g., > 8–10 mm); older age (e.g. > 60 years), heavy nicotine use, and a history of prior cancer (see “Predictors of malignancy risk in patients with SPNs” table). In high-risk nodules > 8 mm (i.e., comprising only high-risk features) a surgical biopsy should be obtained and treatment should be initiated depending on the results. A PET-CT is indicated for patients with intermediate (i.e., both high and low-risk features) or low-risk nodules (i.e., comprising only low-risk features) > 8 mm. Nodules ≤ 8 mm can be followed up with serial CT scans. Surveillance frequency is determined by the patient's malignancy risk and nodule size.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window)

A spiculated mass (green overlay) is present in the right upper lobe. A small nodule is also visible medial to the mass.
questions.hint: The presence of certain clinical and radiographic features can help determine the risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules and guide further management.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents for follow-up after a visit 2 months ago for increased dyspnea on exertion. He has smoked approximately two packs of cigarettes per day since he was 20 years old and drinks three to four alcoholic beverages per night. He works as a regional office manager for a national construction company. He states that his older brother recently died of lung cancer and wonders what he can do to reduce his own risk of dying from lung cancer.
Since his last visit, his evaluation has included chest radiographs, ambulatory oxygen saturation measurements, and spirometry.
His spirometry shows an FEV1 of 1.94 liters (45% of predicted), an FVC of 3.32 liters (83% of predicted), and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 58%.
His oxygen saturation at rest is 95% while he is breathing ambient air. During exertion, his oxygen saturation drops to 93%.
The chest radiographs are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
In addition to smoking cessation, which one of the following interventions is most likely to reduce the risk for mortality from lung cancer in this patient?

choices.text: Yearly low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Epidemiologic and experimental studies support the claim that cigarette smoking is a major risk factor for the development of malignancy — in particular, lung cancer. The single most important lifestyle modification to prevent lung cancer is smoking cessation. Although there is evidence that alcohol use and asbestos exposure increase the risk for developing cancer, the associations are not as robust as that between cigarette smoking and cancer. Smoking cessation should be encouraged in this patient, and appropriate resources (counseling, pharmacologic treatments, follow-up) should be provided.

Given the high incidence and mortality associated with pulmonary cancers, there have been numerous attempts to develop effective screening methods to detect early-stage lung cancers. The only modality that has shown a survival benefit is yearly low-dose CT of the chest in high-risk patients. Most current guidelines recommend annual screening with low-dose chest CT for people age 50 to 80 years who have a history of at least 20 pack-years of cigarette smoking and either currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years.

Key learning point: The screening method shown to reduce the risk for lung-cancer mortality in high-risk individuals is low-dose CT of the chest.

B) INCORRECT:

Although there is indirect evidence that treating chronic obstructive lung disease may reduce the risk for cancer, the studies are small and focus on the use of inhaled glucocorticoids; there is no evidence that using albuterol or tiotropium before exertion reduces mortality from lung cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Although there is indirect evidence that treating chronic obstructive lung disease may reduce the risk for cancer, the studies are small and focus on the use of inhaled glucocorticoids; there is no evidence that using albuterol or tiotropium before exertion reduces mortality from lung cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that the patient's ambulatory oxygen saturation remains above 88% even with exertion, he does not require supplemental oxygen. Supplemental oxygen has been shown to reduce mortality risk in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease by slowing the progression of right heart failure. It does not reduce the risk for developing or dying from lung cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Yearly chest radiographs show no survival benefit.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman who has never smoked is seen for a routine visit. She is concerned about developing lung cancer, given that her mother, grandmother, and aunt, who all were smokers, died from lung cancer. She wants to know if there are any exposures other than smoking that might increase her risk of lung cancer.
Which one of the following substances has been shown to be associated with an increased risk of lung cancer in observational studies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exposure to ozone or food preservatives has not been shown to cause lung cancer.

B) CORRECT:

Although smoking is the number one risk factor for lung cancer, other exposures, including ionizing radiation, can also increase this risk. One source of ionizing radiation is radon, a decay product of uranium and radium. In some regions of the world, high indoor levels of radon are common. It is reasonably well established that environmental radon exposure (e.g., in mines) increases the risk of lung cancer. The data on residential radon and lung cancer risk shows a smaller magnitude of effect, but several observational studies have confirmed a slight increase in risk with residential radon exposure.

Key learning point: Observational studies have found that the risk of lung cancer is increased by environmental exposure to radon.

C) INCORRECT:

Exposure to bird or mold antigens is linked to respiratory conditions such as hypersensitivity pneumonitis, but neither one is associated with increased risk for lung cancer.

D) INCORRECT:
