Exposure to bird or mold antigens is linked to respiratory conditions such as hypersensitivity pneumonitis, but neither one is associated with increased risk for lung cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Exposure to ozone or food preservatives has not been shown to cause lung cancer.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman with a 65-pack-year history of cigarette smoking is hospitalized with one month of progressively worsening dyspnea. Her medical history is notable only for hypothyroidism.
CT of the chest reveals a 2.5-cm mass obstructing the lingular segment of the left-upper lobe. No abnormal-appearing lymph nodes are detected.
A diagnostic bronchoscopy with endobronchial biopsies is performed. Pathology is positive for adenocarcinoma. Additional testing for a mutation in the epidermal growth factor receptor gene is positive.
Further imaging studies — including CT of the abdomen and pelvis, MRI of the brain, and positron emission tomography — reveal no findings that suggest metastases. Pulmonary function tests demonstrate normal results except for a slightly decreased (82%) total lung capacity.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Surgical resection, adjuvant chemotherapy, and radiotherapy
Surgical resection and treatment with erlotinib

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The most appropriate treatment for stage IA non-small-cell lung cancer in a patient with no other comorbidities is surgical resection alone. Postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy has not been found to benefit patients with stage IA disease after surgical resection. Radiotherapy is not appropriate in this case, because the added benefit does not outweigh the associated complications.

B) INCORRECT:

The most appropriate treatment for stage IA non-small-cell lung cancer in a patient with no other comorbidities is surgical resection alone.

C) INCORRECT:

The most appropriate treatment for stage IA non-small-cell lung cancer in a patient with no other comorbidities is surgical resection alone.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has stage IA non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). In stage IA disease, the tumor is ≤3 cm in diameter, is limited to one lung, and does not involve the mediastinum, lymph nodes, or more distant sites. (This patient has a T1c tumor of 2 to 3 cm, N0, M0). Surgery is the standard treatment for patients such as this who have clinical stage I or II disease.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for stage IA non-small-cell lung cancer in a patient with no other comorbidities is surgical resection alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase mutations are present in approximately 15% of non-small-cell lung cancer adenocarcinomas. In advanced stages, the presence of this mutation confers a more favorable prognosis and predicts sensitivity to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as erlotinib. No study to date has shown that treatment with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors after complete resection confers a mortality benefit; thus, it is not considered as an adjunctive therapy in the setting of surgical treatment of early-stage NSCLC.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman reports several months of a persistent cough that produces white sputum. One month ago, she noted transient blood streaks in the sputum that developed during an episode of acute bronchitis. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and has a 44-pack-year history. She is otherwise well.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
In addition to smoking-cessation counseling, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Complete blood count and coagulation studies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing is useful in evaluating for underlying obstructive or restrictive disease, but these conditions are less likely to manifest with the symptoms described in this case. In addition, such testing would not help establish whether there is a malignancy, which is a much likelier diagnosis in this case.

B) CORRECT:

Lung cancer is the most common malignancy, so it is critical to recognize the nonspecific signs and symptoms in high-risk patients with a history of smoking. Cough is reported by up to 75% of patients who are diagnosed with a pulmonary malignancy. Hemoptysis occurs in up to 50% of patients with a pulmonary malignancy, although bronchitis is the most frequent cause of this symptom. Either of these symptoms could signal an underlying malignancy.

A normal chest radiograph has <50% sensitivity for detecting early lung cancers. The most appropriate diagnostic test is CT of the chest.

Key learning point: In a patient whose clinical presentation is highly suspicious for lung cancer, the most appropriate diagnostic test is CT of the chest.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating a chest radiograph in 3 months is inappropriate, given its low sensitivity for detecting malignant lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Fiberoptic bronchoscopy can be useful in diagnosing lung cancer, but CT is more appropriate for initial localization of the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count and coagulation studies are unlikely to aid in diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman has a 30-pack-year history of smoking and continues to smoke daily. She does not take any medications. A review of her systems is unremarkable.
She had a normal colonoscopy 5 years ago, an unremarkable chest radiograph and mammogram 6 months ago, and a normal Pap test 6 months ago.
Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Low-dose helical CT of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian ultrasound screenings are not proven to reduce cancer mortality.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the breasts is not warranted in a patient with a recent normal mammography and no suspicion for genetic susceptibility to breast cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat colonoscopy and fecal occult-blood testing are not indicated in a patient with a normal colonoscopy within the past 5 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat colonoscopy and fecal occult-blood testing are not indicated in a patient with a normal colonoscopy within the past 5 years.

E) CORRECT:

The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends annual screening for lung cancer in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20-pack-year history of cigarette smoking and either currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. The preferred screening method is low-dose helical CT of the chest rather than a single chest radiograph or annual chest radiography. In one large study, CT-screened patients had a 20% relative reduction in lung cancer-related mortality, compared with unscreened patients.

Key learning point: In patients aged 50 to 80 years who either currently smoke or have a history of heavy smoking (>20 pack-years), lung cancer screening should be conducted using low-dose helical CT of the chest.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old woman with a 55-pack-year history of smoking is evaluated for a nodule in the upper lobe of her right lung. She recently presented to an outpatient clinic with a several-week history of nonproductive cough. She reports no hemoptysis, unintentional weight loss, or night sweats. She is able to walk a mile without experiencing any dyspnea or chest pain.
Her workup included a chest radiograph that showed an abnormal density. On CT imaging, the nodule measures 2.5 cm in diameter (figure). The remainder of the lung parenchyma is normal in appearance, no enlarged lymph nodes are evident, and there are no suspicious liver or adrenal lesions.
A full-body positron emission tomography scan reveals that the only metabolically active site is the lung nodule. Brain MRI reveals no abnormalities. Appropriate pulmonary function testing shows no abnormalities.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain sputum for acid-fast bacilli stain and culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sputum evaluation for tuberculosis would be of relatively low yield in a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule.

B) INCORRECT:

Transbronchial biopsy of the nodule could yield a diagnosis of cancer, but the nodule would still need to be excised after a positive biopsy. Moreover, when the pre-test probability of malignancy is high, a negative biopsy would not sufficiently rule out malignancy because of the possibility of sampling error, and excision of the nodule would still be recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Sputum cytology would be of relatively low yield in a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with an extensive history of smoking, a pulmonary nodule detected on CT is likely to be malignant if it has a spiculated appearance and measures ≥2.3 cm in diameter.

Several validated models are available to assist clinicians in predicting the likelihood of malignancy. One commonly used model, from Brock University, includes the following risk factors:

• Female sex
• Age >35 years
• Family history of lung cancer
• Emphysema
• Larger nodule size (the risk of cancer increases as nodule size increases)
• Location of the nodule in the upper lobe
• Partially solid nodule
• Lower nodule count (fewer nodules are more predictive of malignancy)
• Spiculated appearance of the nodule

According to this model, the probability of malignancy in this nodule is at least 70%.

If the patient has no contraindication to surgery and there is no evidence of metastatic disease, the most appropriate next step is referral to a thoracic surgeon. Excision of the nodule would enable both treatment and diagnosis of the suspected malignancy.

CT-guided biopsy or transbronchial biopsy of the nodule could yield a diagnosis of cancer, but the nodule would still need to be excised after a positive biopsy. Moreover, when the pre-test probability of malignancy is high, a negative biopsy would not sufficiently rule out malignancy because of the possibility of sampling error, and excision of the nodule would still be recommended.

Repeat imaging and clinical follow-up (with no intervention) would each confer an unacceptably high risk for cancer progression.

Sputum cytology or sputum evaluation for tuberculosis would be of relatively low yield in a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule.

Key learning point: A patient with an extensive history of smoking and a 2.5-cm, malignant-appearing, solitary pulmonary nodule detected on CT without evidence of metastatic disease on positron emission tomography and brain MRI should be referred for surgical excision of the nodule, provided that the patient has no contraindication to surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

CT-guided biopsy of the nodule could yield a diagnosis of cancer, but the nodule would still need to be excised after a positive biopsy. Moreover, when the pre-test probability of malignancy is high, a negative biopsy would not sufficiently rule out malignancy because of the possibility of sampling error, and excision of the nodule would still be recommended.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 40-pack-year history of cigarette smoking reports 3 months of right shoulder pain that radiates down her arm. Her symptoms have persisted and progressed despite a course of physical therapy and use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications and acetaminophen.
On examination, her right shoulder has full range of motion and is not swollen or tender to palpation. She has wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the right hand. Lung examination is remarkable for mild bilateral expiratory wheezing. Palpation of her right axilla reveals no masses.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve-conduction studies in the right arm are likely to suggest a brachial plexopathy but will not reveal its cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with a significant history of cigarette smoking, the presence of shoulder pain with muscle wasting in the ipsilateral distal extremity and a normal shoulder examination should suggest the possibility of an upper thoracic tumor compressing or invading the brachial plexus. These tumors, called superior pulmonary sulcus or Pancoast tumors, are typically due to non-small-cell lung cancers. The pain that patients experience is due to invasion of the tumor into the brachial plexus or through extension of the tumor into the parietal pleura, ribs, or vertebra. These tumors can also invade the sympathetic chain and inferior cervical ganglion and cause Horner syndrome. The most appropriate next step is to obtain a chest radiograph.

Key learning point: Shoulder pain and wasting of the small muscles of the hand in a patient with a long history of cigarette smoking should prompt evaluation for superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast tumor) with a chest radiograph.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A heterogeneous mass-like opacity (red overlay) in the right apex extends to a thickened irregular pleural surface (blue overlay). Other vague areas of soft tissue density are also present in the right apex (green overlay), and the posterior cortices of the right 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs (indicated by white dashed outlines) are not fully visualized as a result of tumor invasion.

The findings are consistent with a Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine disease can manifest with pain that radiates to the shoulder or radicular neurologic findings in the arm; however, the first priority in this case is to rule out a superior pulmonary sulcus tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman in an assisted living facility presents for evaluation of slowly progressive “deep” pain in the thighs and shins that has lasted for 3 to 4 months. She also notes discomfort and thickening of her fingertips. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes, mild dementia, and a 40-pack-year history of cigarette smoking. Review of systems identifies fatigue, a cough that occasionally produces a small amount of blood, and 9.1 kg of unintended weight loss during the past 6 months.
On examination, the patient is afebrile and has normal vital signs. Heart, lung, and abdomen examinations are unremarkable. Neither the thighs nor the shins are tender to the touch, and there is full range of motion of both knees and ankles. There is prominent clubbing of the fingers with bulbous widening at the fingertips and mild erythema at the nail beds.
Laboratory evaluation reveals normal leukocyte and platelet counts, as well as a normal serum creatinine level for the patient’s age and normal results on liver function tests. The patient has a hematocrit of 32% (reference range, 36–46), an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 62 mm/hr (1–25), and a C-reactive protein level of 18 mg/liter (0.08–3.10).
A chest radiograph is normal.
A whole-body nuclear bone scan is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis and echocardiography are not useful in the absence of other signs or symptoms of cardiovascular and genitourinary disease, which are not typically associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis and echocardiography are not useful in the absence of other signs or symptoms of cardiovascular and genitourinary disease, which are not typically associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

C) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is characterized by finger clubbing, widening of the fingertips, arthritis, and periostitis with periosteal thickening at long bones. It is often associated with chronic hypoxia, as is found in patients with cystic fibrosis and congenital heart disease. Although mild finger clubbing has been described in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), severe clubbing or hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is not seen with COPD alone. If a patient with COPD or a patient who smokes develops significant finger clubbing, lung cancer — in particular, bronchogenic carcinoma — should be suspected. In this older patient with a history of cigarette smoking, recognition of hypertrophic osteopathy should prompt an evaluation for lung cancer with CT of the chest.

Key learning point: Clubbing and widening of the fingertips, arthritis, periostitis, and periosteal thickening at long bones are associated with a diagnosis of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests help characterize the physiologic impact of lung disease but are not of primary diagnostic importance.

E) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen may be helpful in further evaluating for malignancy but would not be the first choice, because hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is less frequently associated with gastrointestinal malignancies than with pulmonary malignancies, particularly in a patient with risk factors for lung cancer.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman reports to the emergency department with a 3-month history of increasing difficulty getting out of chairs, climbing stairs, and managing daily activities. She can no longer get out of bed herself and reports weakness, easy bruising, worsening of her chronic cough, and weight loss of 9.1 kg.
Her medical history is notable only for osteoarthritis of the knee, for which she takes ibuprofen as needed, and mild contact dermatitis controlled with the use of over-the-counter hydrocortisone lotion. She reports no use of diuretics. She is retired, has smoked 10 cigarettes per day for the past 50 years, and drinks one to two alcoholic drinks per week.
On physical examination, her blood pressure is 163/88 mm Hg. She is thin, has marked proximal muscle weakness, and has several bruises on her forearms and shins.
Laboratory evaluation reveals the following levels:



Patient value
Reference range



Potassium (mEq/liter)
2.2
3.5–5.0


Sodium (mEq/liter)
143
136–145



Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
34
21–30


Chloride (mEq/liter)
98
98–106



Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
193
70–100


What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism is a genetic disease and would not have its onset at an older age.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone cream is not very potent, so its use is unlikely to be associated with the rapidly progressive features of Cushing syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

An ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma or a cortisol-producing adrenocortical adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome, but they are usually slower to progress than ectopic ACTH production and more likely to be associated with weight gain rather than weight loss. In these two conditions, signs and symptoms of cortisol excess (e.g., weight gain, centripetal adiposity, and proximal myopathy) dominate the clinical presentation. Hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis are not features of mild or moderate hypercortisolism.

D) INCORRECT:

An ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma or a cortisol-producing adrenocortical adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome, but they are usually slower to progress than ectopic ACTH production and more likely to be associated with weight gain rather than weight loss. In these two conditions, signs and symptoms of cortisol excess (e.g., weight gain, centripetal adiposity, and proximal myopathy) dominate the clinical presentation. Hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis are not features of mild or moderate hypercortisolism.

E) CORRECT:

Ectopic production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is seen in many tumors, particularly small-cell lung carcinomas, and occurs in patients with rapidly progressive Cushing syndrome. There may be modest physical findings of cortisol excess, but metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hyperglycemia) dominate the clinical presentation because of the severe and usually sudden onset of hypercortisolism. There are multiple potential causes of the patient’s hypokalemia and hyperglycemia. However, in cases where symptoms are rapidly progressive and associated with weight loss and marked metabolic abnormalities, ectopic ACTH production is the most likely diagnosis. The weight loss is caused by the underlying cancer.

Key learning point: New-onset metabolic abnormalities associated with Cushing syndrome (e.g., hypokalemia or hyperglycemia) with only modest findings of cortisol excess on physical examination is most consistent with ectopic production of adrenocorticotropic hormone.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with hypertension, insulin-requiring diabetes mellitus, end-stage kidney disease, and a distant history of cigarette smoking presents with new-onset pain in her right shoulder and weakness in her right hand that have progressed during the past 6 weeks. In addition, she has lost 15 pounds during the past 4 months.
Physical examination reveals a unilateral, right-sided ptosis with a pinpoint pupil of the right eye, as well as muscle atrophy, hand weakness, and numbness in the fourth and fifth fingers of the right hand. No facial plethora is noted. The patient has no pain on percussion of her neck or back.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis leads to renal insufficiency and can cause sensorimotor neuropathy but is not associated with the development of Horner syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Although myasthenia gravis can cause ptosis and muscle weakness, it is not associated with miosis (a component of Horner syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

Although carotid artery dissection could progress to stroke and subsequently cause arm weakness, this event would likely occur more acutely than the gradual development of Horner syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Tumors of the superior pulmonary sulcus, also called Pancoast tumors, can cause a classic presentation by compressing against nerve structures as they pass through or near the thoracic inlet. Compression of the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots can cause pain and neurologic compromise of those nerves. In addition, interruption of the sympathetic nerve chain running to the head can result in Horner syndrome, which is characterized by unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis. Treatment of superior pulmonary sulcus tumors involves multidisciplinary care coordinated among a thoracic surgeon, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist.

Key learning point: The gradual development of arm weakness and Horner syndrome in an older patient with a history of cigarette smoking is most indicative of a diagnosis of a superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Arm weakness and numbness in the fingers is more consistent with a dermatomal distribution than with a brainstem lesion.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 30-pack-year history of cigarette smoking is admitted to the hospital for a productive cough and dyspnea. She was treated for a right-upper-lobe pneumonia about 4 weeks ago. Her symptoms initially improved with levofloxacin, but during the past 3 weeks, she has had a worsening cough, dyspnea, fatigue, and anorexia.
On examination, the patient is thin and afebrile with a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Her lung examination is significant for long expiratory wheezes with decreased breath sounds in her upper right chest. A chest radiograph reveals a right-upper-lobe opacity that is unchanged from her chest radiograph 3 weeks ago.
Which one of the following strategies is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The prolonged time course and clinical picture in this case are not consistent with Legionella infection. In addition, the patient was appropriately treated for legionellosis with a fluoroquinolone antibiotic and has continuing symptoms. This clinical picture could be consistent with mycobacterial infection. Based on the results of the CT scan, evaluation for mycobacterial infection might also be pursued.

B) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography is useful for evaluating early-stage lung cancers for lymph-node involvement or metastatic disease, but it would not be appropriate until a diagnosis of lung cancer has been made.

C) CORRECT:

Patents with a history of heavy cigarette smoking and a pneumonia that does not resolve after treatment with antibiotics should be evaluated for an underlying neoplasm. Lung cancers can cause a postobstructive pneumonia or look like an infiltrate on chest radiograph. Chest CT is the most helpful initial test to characterize any possible underlying masses or lymphadenopathy. If anything suspicious is seen on the CT scan, either a CT-guided biopsy or a bronchoscopy with biopsy can be pursued.

Key learning point: Patients with a persistent lung opacity and a history of heavy cigarette smoking should undergo chest CT to evaluate for an underlying neoplasm of the lung.

D) INCORRECT:

Although bronchoscopy may be indicated for further evaluation of a potential lung cancer, this would not be done without a chest CT to better guide the procedure. The best approach to diagnosis would also include transbronchial biopsy and potentially lymph-node sampling to stage the malignancy. All of this would be done after better evaluation with a chest CT.

E) INCORRECT:

Additional antibiotics would not be appropriate in this case until a primary lung cancer has been ruled out. Furthermore, combination therapy with a beta-lactam and a macrolide would be more appropriate than a beta-lactam alone for a patient who has failed therapy with a respiratory fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman with well-controlled chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 50-pack-year history of cigarette smoking is diagnosed with non-small-cell lung cancer after presenting with weight loss, cough, and pain in the upper chest and shoulders. Cross-sectional imaging reveals metastases in both lungs and in the liver as well as possible lesions in the spine. An MRI of the spine is obtained (figure).
Functionally, the patient is able to perform all activities of daily living with some assistance. She has some symptoms and limitations as a consequence of her cancer.
In addition to platinum-based chemotherapy, which one of the following interventions is most likely to prolong survival in this patient?

choices.text: Engage the patient with palliative care services

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Zoledronic acid can prevent pathological fractures and hypercalcemia related to her bone metastases but has not been shown to prolong survival.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s MRI shows metastases to the spine but with no radiologic features of impending fracture, and there is no report of symptoms correlating to the metastases. In this setting, spinal irradiation would not be expected to provide benefit.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids would not be expected to have a major impact in the treatment of metastatic NSCLC.

D) CORRECT:

A randomized study of 151 patients with newly diagnosed non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) showed that adding early palliative care to standard oncologic care improved both quality of life and mood. Patients in the early palliative-care group had less aggressive care at the end of life but achieved significantly longer survival than those in the standard-care group. Palliative care also improves the quality of death.

Key learning point: In addition to platinum-based chemotherapy, the intervention that has been shown to prolong survival for an older patient with newly diagnosed metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer is early referral to palliative care.

E) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic cranial irradiation provides a survival benefit in small-cell lung cancer and may reduce the incidence of brain metastases in NSCLC, but it has not been shown to prolong survival in NSCLC.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man who has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since the age of 15 undergoes screening for lung cancer with his first low-dose screening CT of the chest. The scan shows a single 6-mm solid nodule in the right lower lobe. No other abnormalities are noted.
The patient’s medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia.
In addition to facilitating smoking cessation, what is the most appropriate next step in evaluation and management?

choices.text: Combination positron emission tomography and CT
Follow-up low-dose CT of the chest in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In multiple trials, screening with chest radiography has not been shown to reduce lung-cancer mortality.

B) INCORRECT:

Combination positron emission tomography and CT is not recommended for the characterization of small pulmonary nodules.

C) INCORRECT:

Biopsy would be appropriate only if the nodule was shown to increase in size on serial imaging.

D) CORRECT:

In the National Lung Screening Trial, the use of low-dose chest CT to screen smokers significantly reduced lung-cancer mortality (although the absolute reduction in mortality was small, and false-positive scans were common). The Lung-RADS assessment categories, developed by the American College of Radiology (Lung CT Screening Reporting and Data System), are the most commonly used criteria to guide decision-making around further workup of pulmonary nodules detected on screening CT. The intensity of follow-up depends on the characteristics of the nodule, including its size and appearance. According to these criteria, a 6-mm solid nodule found on baseline screening CT can be categorized as “probably benign” and should be followed up with a low-dose chest CT in 6 months.

Pulmonary nodules that are detected incidentally on chest CT scans performed for other reasons are followed in a slightly different fashion, most commonly guided by the Fleischner criteria, which also take into consideration patient risk factors (e.g., smoking status). The Lung-RADS criteria are preferred in this scenario because they are specifically targeted to patients who undergo screening CT and are, by definition, at higher risk.

Key learning point: The recommended follow-up for a smoker who is found to have a single solid pulmonary nodule 6 to 8 mm in size on a baseline screening CT for lung cancer is a follow-up low-dose CT scan of the chest in 6 months.

E) INCORRECT:

The Lung-RADS assessment categories, developed by the American College of Radiology (Lung CT Screening Reporting and Data System), are the most commonly used criteria to guide decision-making around further workup of pulmonary nodules detected on screening CT. According to these criteria, a 6-mm solid nodule found on baseline screening CT can be categorized as “probably benign” and should be followed up with a low-dose chest CT in 6 months.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man returns for evaluation after fine-needle aspiration of a spiculated, 3.6-cm peripheral right lung mass confirms a diagnosis of non-small-cell lung cancer. Symptoms of the lung cancer consisted of a persistent cough and occasional hemoptysis during the past 3 months. His medical history is significant for hypertension, hypothyroidism, and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His physical examination is unremarkable.
Combination positron emission tomography and CT reveals several right hilar and subcarinal lymph nodes, the largest measuring 1.2 cm, that are not 18 F-fluorodeoxyglucose-avid. No other enlarged lymph nodes or metastatic lesions are noted. An MRI of the brain reveals no evidence of intracranial metastases.
Which one of the following management steps is the most appropriate next step in this case?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the primary tumor and the lung lobe that contains it

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchoalveolar lavage would not allow for tissue access of the lymph nodes.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is a potential treatment but would not be appropriate until after staging with lymph-node biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation of the primary lesion is a potential treatment but would not be appropriate until after staging with lymph-node biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is a potential treatment but would not be appropriate until after staging with lymph-node biopsy.

E) CORRECT:

Proper staging for non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is essential to determine appropriate treatment modalities. NSCLC staging uses the tumor-node-metastasis (TNM) system. A lung cancer measuring 3.6 cm is, by definition, T2a per TNM classifications (T1 tumors are <3 cm in size).

Determining the nodal stage is crucial for treatment decision-making in patients with T2 tumors, especially when the patient has suspicious lymph nodes on imaging, because the involvement of lymph nodes will alter treatment. Although positron emission tomography can help clarify the nature of lymphadenopathy, it is not sufficiently sensitive or specific to obviate the need for biopsy. Another method of assessing the mediastinal nodes is endobronchial ultrasound-guided transbronchial node aspiration. Some centers prefer this method of assessing the mediastinum. The key point is that the mediastinum must be assessed and found free of tumor to proceed with curative resection. Thus, of the answer options listed, mediastinoscopy and lymph-node sampling are the best choice.

• A patient whose lymph nodes are negative for cancer would have a T2aN0M0 stage IB lung cancer. Treatment is surgical resection (in operable candidates).
• Patients with positive ipsilateral lymph nodes would have a T2aN2M0 stage IIIA lung cancer. Multimodality therapy usually includes neoadjuvant treatment (chemotherapy with or without radiation) followed by surgery.
• Patients with positive contralateral lymph nodes would have a T2aN3M0 stage IIIB lung cancer, which is treated with a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

Key learning point: The next step in the management of a patient who has a recently detected isolated 3.6-cm lung mass, confirmed to be non-small-cell lung cancer on fine-needle aspiration, with suspicious lymph nodes on imaging is lymph-node biopsy.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her husband, who reports that she has been disoriented for several days and is unable to recognize him. He reports that her cognition was completely intact a week ago. The patient’s medical history is significant for hypertension, well-controlled type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Her daily medications include amlodipine 10 mg, metformin 500 mg, and simvastatin 20 mg.
She reports a 60-pack-year history of cigarette smoking and denies any history of alcohol or illicit drug use. Ten years ago, she retired from her job working as a manager of a steel mill, where she believes that she may have been exposed to asbestos.
Her physical examination is unremarkable, with the exception of diffuse wheezes in all lung fields and a barrel chest. She is oriented only to her name, but her neurological examination is otherwise normal.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
139
136–145


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
13
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.7
0.6–1.1


Glucose (mg/dL)
102
70–100



Calcium (mg/dL)
14.4
9.0–10.5



Ionized calcium (mg/dL)
7.0
4.5–5.6


Albumin (g/dL)
3.6
3.5–5.5



Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
3
10–60


An MRI of the head shows no evidence of ischemia or tumors. A chest radiograph reveals a 4.3-cm mass in the center of her right lung. Further workup for other sites of suspected malignancy is negative.
Which one of the following types of cancer is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small-cell lung cancer can produce a variety of ectopic hormones, including adrenocorticotropic hormone and the antidiuretic hormone, such that patients can develop paraneoplastic Cushing syndrome and the syndrome of inappropriate diuretic hormone secretion, respectively.

Parathyroid hormone-related peptide is not typically secreted by small-cell tumors.

B) CORRECT:

Paraneoplastic syndromes are common in specific subtypes of lung cancer. The low level of serum parathyroid hormone in the context of hypercalcemia suggests the presence of parathyroid hormone-related peptide. Squamous-cell lung cancer is associated with the release of parathyroid hormone-related peptide, which acts at the parathyroid hormone receptor and leads to an increase in serum calcium levels. Patients frequently present with signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia, including psychosis, confusion, constipation, abdominal pain, fatigue, myalgias, cardiac arrhythmias, and acute renal failure.

Key learning point: The cancer that is most typically associated with parathyroid hormone-related peptide-induced hypercalcemia is squamous-cell carcinoma of the lung.

C) INCORRECT:

Mesotheliomas most commonly appear as pleural plaques and are not generally associated with paraneoplastic syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Thymomas are tumors of the mediastinum and are most likely to produce antibodies to the acetylcholine receptor, such that patients present with myasthenia gravis.

E) INCORRECT:

Lung adenocarcinoma tends to manifest as a hypertrophic osteoarthropathy and is not typically associated with hypercalcemia.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife to lung cancer asks if there is a test he can take to reduce his own chances of dying from lung cancer. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily from age 16 until age 55, when his wife was diagnosed with lung cancer and they both quit smoking.
He is physically active and reports no symptoms. He has no medical problems except hypertension, which is controlled with medications.
His physical examination and routine laboratory findings are normal.
Which one of the following screening strategies would be most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: One-time thin-slice CT of the lung
One-time combination positron emission tomography and CT of the lung
Annual chest radiographs with sputum cytologic analysis
Annual low-dose CT of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One-time thin-slice CT of the lung, whether alone or in combination with positron emission tomography, is not considered an appropriate screening test for lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

One-time thin-slice CT of the lung, whether alone or in combination with positron emission tomography, is not considered an appropriate screening test for lung cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Randomized trials of screening with chest radiography, with or without cytologic analysis of sputum specimens, have not shown a reduction in lung-cancer mortality.

D) INCORRECT:

Randomized trials of screening with chest radiography, with or without cytologic analysis of sputum specimens, have not shown a reduction in lung-cancer mortality.

E) CORRECT:

The National Lung Screening Trial showed a 20% reduction in lung-cancer mortality among current or former heavy smokers who were screened with low-dose CT for 3 consecutive years, rather than with a single chest radiograph. Although the rate of heavy smoking continues to decline in the United States, 94 million current or former smokers remain at elevated risk for the disease, and lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer death in this country.

Most current guidelines recommend annual screening with low-dose chest CT for people age 50 to 80 years who have a history of at least 20 pack-years of cigarette smoking and either currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years.

Key learning point: In patients at high risk for lung cancer, lung-cancer mortality can be reduced by annual screening with low-dose CT.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a 25-pack-year history of cigarette smoking presents with mild dyspnea, hoarseness, and dysphagia that have progressed during the past 2 weeks.
On examination, her blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation improves from 93% while she is breathing ambient air to 97% when she receives supplemental oxygen (3 liters per minute). She is able to complete full sentences but has to take a break from speaking after a few minutes. She has slight asymmetric facial edema, scattered wheezes, and engorged veins in the neck and on the chest wall.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. CT of the chest shows large, heterogeneous-appearing lymph nodes throughout the mediastinum, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and brachiocephalic vein. Transbronchial biopsy reveals sheets of small, round cells with dark nuclei, typical of small-cell lung cancer.
What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Surgical bypass grafting of the superior vena cava

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bypass of the superior vena cava (SVC) (which uses an autologous femoral vein or spiral saphenous vein graft from the brachiocephalic vein to the right atrium) is usually reserved for nonmalignant SVC obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Stent placement is useful in patients with severe symptoms, such as respiratory distress, that require urgent intervention.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms (facial swelling, dyspnea, and dysphagia) and imaging findings are consistent with a diagnosis of the superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. Management of SVC syndrome associated with cancer involves both treating the cancer and providing relief from the symptoms of obstruction. In patients with small-cell lung cancer, lymphoma, or germ-cell tumors, clinical response to chemotherapy alone (such as cisplatin and etoposide) is generally rapid.

Key learning point: Patients with superior vena cava syndrome from small-cell lung cancer should be treated with chemotherapy (cisplatin and etoposide) as soon as possible.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy is unnecessary unless the patient is presenting urgently with a rapidly developing syndrome, airway compromise, or hemodynamic instability.

E) INCORRECT:

Although glucocorticoids reduce tumor burden in lymphomas and thymomas, they are not typically effective in reducing obstruction of the superior vena cava in patients with small-cell lung cancer.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman presents after a recent diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma with a malignant pleural effusion. She is otherwise healthy, has never smoked, and takes no medications. She has already undergone thoracentesis, which dramatically improved her dyspnea, and is now eager to begin treatment.
Which one of the following types of oncogenic driver mutations is most likely to be associated with this patient's cancer?

choices.text: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) mutations
Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) receptor mutations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

B-lymphocyte antigen CD20 alterations are not associated with lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) mutations can be observed in lung cancer but are less common (occurring in 1% to 3% of patients) than EGFR mutations.

C) INCORRECT:

KIT mutations are commonly associated with gastrointestinal stromal tumors, not lung cancer.

D) CORRECT:

The presence or absence of a history of cigarette smoking affects the clinical presentation of lung cancer. Among patients who develop lung cancer, those without a history of cigarette smoking are more likely than those with such a history:

• To be diagnosed at a younger age
• To be female
• To have well-differentiated adenocarcinomas with a high rate of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations

Given the high rate of EGFR mutations in patients with lung cancer who have never smoked, these patients should be tested for EGFR mutations and for certain other important driver mutations, such as translocations of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene. Patients with EGFR mutations respond well to EGFR inhibitors (osimertinib, erlotinib, or gefitinib), which have less toxicity than chemotherapy.

Key learning point: Patients who are newly diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the lung and have never smoked should be tested for epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutations, as well as certain other important driver mutations.

E) INCORRECT:

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) receptor mutations are not associated with lung cancer.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and a family history of coronary artery disease undergoes CT for the purpose of calculating a coronary artery calcium score and is found to have an incidental pulmonary nodule. The nodule is 7 mm in diameter, located in the right upper lobe, and solid in appearance, without spiculation or internal calcification.
The patient reports that he has no symptoms and specifically denies any exertional dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, night sweats, or fever. He works as an attorney. He has no history of cigarette smoking and no personal or family history of lung cancer. His vital signs are stable, and his lungs are clear on auscultation.
What is the most appropriate follow-up, if any, for this patient?

choices.text: Arrange for CT-guided biopsy of the nodule

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeat chest CT at 3 months can be considered in patients with nodules measuring >8 mm in size, those with multiple nodules, and those with partly solid nodules. For a single solid nodule measuring 6 to 8 mm, as in this case, a 3-month interval between CT scans may be too short to detect any changes and could provide false reassurance.

B) CORRECT:

Solitary pulmonary nodules are commonly detected on CT performed for purposes other than lung cancer screening, and many of these nodules will require further testing. Solid nodules that measure 6 to 8 mm in size, as in this case, should be followed with a repeat CT at 6 to 12 months to monitor for stability. A third CT scan should be obtained at 18 to 24 months in patients who are at high risk for lung cancer and can be considered in those who are at low risk. If the nodule remains unchanged (after two CTs in low-risk patients or three in high-risk patients), no further follow-up is needed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate follow-up for an asymptomatic individual with an incidentally detected single, solid pulmonary nodule measuring 6 to 8 mm in diameter is a repeat chest CT in 6 to 12 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that the risk of lung cancer increases with the size of the nodule, all incidental pulmonary nodules ≥6 mm that cannot be compared to prior imaging for stability should be followed with a repeat chest CT. Depending on clinical risks for lung cancer, smaller nodules may also need to be followed.

D) INCORRECT:

Depending on the clinical scenario and other radiographic features, tissue sampling with CT-guided biopsy may be appropriate for incidental pulmonary nodules >8 mm in size in individuals at high risk for lung cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

PET/CT can be considered in patients with nodules measuring >8 mm in size and may even be preferable to CT at 3 months in some of these individuals. It is not appropriate for nodules measuring ≤8 mm or for partly solid nodules, as it could lead to false results with such nodules.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and stage 3 chronic kidney disease presents for evaluation of a persistent dry cough for the past 3 months. She is otherwise in her normal state of health and denies any fevers, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Her medications include insulin aspart via an insulin pump, losartan, atorvastatin, and aspirin.
She has never smoked cigarettes and does not consume alcohol or use illicit substances. She lives in Kentucky and is fond of camping and hiking. She has no pets or exposures to animals. Her family history is remarkable for asthma in her father and sarcoidosis in her brother. A routine mammogram performed 2 months ago was negative.
On physical examination, she appears well and has a temperature of 37.1°C, a blood pressure of 128/76 mm Hg, a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. She has no rashes or other skin lesions.
A chest radiograph reveals a nodule in the right upper lobe. No prior chest radiographs are available. High-resolution chest CT without contrast confirms the presence of a smooth, well-circumscribed, solid, 2.0-cm, noncalcified nodule in the right upper lobe without evidence of other pulmonary abnormalities. Tests for serum antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies and urine Histoplasma antigen are negative.
Which one of the following next steps is best for this patient?

choices.text: Repeat chest CT at 6 to 12 months
Integrated positron emission tomography and CT

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytology obtained from sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is not sufficiently sensitive to rule out malignancy in the setting of a solitary pulmonary nodule and is therefore not recommended in this case. In some cases, patients may opt to proceed directly to biopsy, which has greater diagnostic yield than either sputum or BAL cytology.

B) INCORRECT:

Although sarcoidosis can manifest as multiple pulmonary nodules, a single nodule would be atypical. Additionally, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels are not useful for diagnosis of sarcoidosis given the low sensitivity and specificity of the test. A biopsy would be the best way to diagnose sarcoidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

CT follow-up at 6 to 12 months would be an appropriate next step for a nodule that is 6 to 8 mm in diameter, according to Fleischner Society guidelines. However, it would not be adequate for a nodule >8 mm in size (as in this case).

D) INCORRECT:

Sputum culture for fungal infection (histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, or coccidioidomycosis) is insensitive and may pose a biohazard risk. Serologic or antigen testing is recommended to rule out these pulmonary infections.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a solitary pulmonary nodule, which is defined as a single nodule between 4 mm and 30 mm in diameter. Lesions greater than 30 mm are called masses and are presumed to be malignant until proven otherwise. The main differential diagnoses for a solitary pulmonary nodule include:

• Malignancy
- Primary lung cancer
- Metastatic cancer
• Infections
- Endemic fungi
- Mycobacteria
• Benign tumors
- Hamartoma
- Fibroma
• Inflammatory conditions
- Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly referred to as Wegener’s granulomatosis)
- Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss)
- Sarcoidosis

Most solitary pulmonary nodules are asymptomatic. If the patient has signs or symptoms suggestive of a pulmonary infection including fever, night sweats, weight loss, and cough with sputum production, then it is reasonable to pursue an infectious workup with sputum and serologic studies for bacteria, mycobacteria, and endemic fungi. However, many of these symptoms are nonspecific and could be present in malignancy as well; thus, further diagnostic workup should be pursued if an infection is not identified and the nodule persists.

According to recommendations from the American College of Chest Physicians, appropriate evaluation for a solid, indeterminate pulmonary nodule (i.e., a nodule without characteristic benign features such as clear calcifications in a benign pattern, intranodular fat pathognomonic of a hamartoma, or a feeding artery and vein typical of an arteriovenous malformation) begins with a comparison to any previous chest imaging. If this comparison shows that the nodule has been stable for the past 2 years, no further follow-up is needed. If the comparison shows nodule growth during the past 2 years, then biopsy or resection is indicated. If no previous imaging is available (as in this case), or nodule growth is equivocal, follow-up depends on the probability of malignancy.

Several validated models are available to assist clinicians in predicting the likelihood of malignancy. One commonly used model, from Brock University, includes the following risk factors:

• Female sex
• Age >35 years
• Family history of lung cancer
• Emphysema
• Larger nodule size (the risk of cancer increases as nodule size increases)
• Location of the nodule in the upper lobe
• Partially solid nodule
• Lower nodule count (fewer nodules are more predictive of malignancy)
• Spiculated appearance of the nodule

Among patients with a solid solitary pulmonary nodule >8 mm in size, those who have a low probability of malignancy (<5%) can be followed with a repeat chest CT in 3 months. Those who have an intermediate probability (5%–65%) should undergo integrated positron emission tomography and CT (PET/CT), and those with a high probability (>65%) should undergo nodule resection.

Given this patient’s risk factors (female sex, age >35, 2.0-cm nodule in the right upper lobe), she has an intermediate probability of malignancy and should undergo PET/CT to further characterize the nodule. In solid pulmonary nodules >8 mm in size, the degree of uptake on a PET scan can help differentiate between a benign nodule (low uptake) and a malignant one (high uptake). In subsolid nodules, such as those with ground-glass portions, the sensitivity and specificity of a PET scan are much lower; this can result in false-negative results, such as in tumors that are less metabolically active (e.g., some adenocarcinomas).

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in the workup of a 2.0-cm, solid, noncalcified solitary pulmonary nodule in a nonsmoker with an intermediate risk of malignancy is integrated positron emission tomography and CT.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of one episode of severe coughing with blood-tinged sputum. He reports a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath on mild exertion, fatigue, and a 5.5-kg (12-lb) weight loss due to decreased appetite. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He appears tired. Physical examination shows gynecomastia and reduced breath sounds on auscultation over the right upper lung field. An x-ray of the chest reveals a 4-cm solitary mass with irregular borders in the periphery of the right upper lobe. A photomicrograph of the lung tissue biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung cancer has a strong association with smoking. However, chest imaging in small cell lung cancer typically shows a centrally located mass, and biopsy results typically show features of neuroendocrine tumors such as small, dark blue cells (Kulchitsky cells) and histological markers such as chromogranin A and synaptophysin.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are sheets of small, dark blue, cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm (enterochromaffin cells).

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Lung adenocarcinoma is the most common type of primary lung cancer and typically appears as a peripheral mass on chest imaging. However, biopsy in lung adenocarcinoma typically shows mucin-producing glandular tumor cells rather than the findings seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.

C) INCORRECT:

A bronchial carcinoid tumor can manifest with symptoms caused by the mass (e.g., cough, hemoptysis) and a peripheral lesion on chest imaging, but it rarely causes weight loss. Moreover, biopsy in a bronchial carcinoid tumor shows features of neuroendocrine tumors such as small, dark blue cells (Kulchitsky cells) and histological markers including chromogranin A and synaptophysin.

D) INCORRECT:

Lung squamous cell carcinoma has a strong association with smoking, but chest imaging in this condition typically shows a centrally located cavitary lesion, and a biopsy discloses nests of atypical squamous cells, keratin pearls, and intercellular bridges.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E staining; high magnification)

There are several nests (example indicated by yellow overlay) composed of large, polygonal, atypical squamous cells with polymorphic nuclei, intercellular bridges (examples indicated by arrowheads) and evidence of keratinization (examples indicated by blue circles).

These are the classic features of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with keratinization. In lung tissue, the presence of SCC can represent primary SCC of the lung or metastasis of an extrapulmonary SCC (more common). Therefore, initial diagnosis in biopsy material requires clinical exclusion of a primary extrapulmonary SCC (e.g., pharyngolaryngeal or anogenital).

E) CORRECT:

Large cell carcinoma is a lung cancer that has a strong association with smoking and typically has a peripheral location on chest imaging. Ectopic production of β-hCG by this tumor can result in gynecomastia. Histopathology shows highly undifferentiated cells that lack identifiable glandular, squamous, or neuroendocrine elements on microscopy or immunohistochemistry. Definitive diagnosis requires completely excised surgical specimens. Large cell carcinoma has a poor prognosis due to early metastases and low response to chemotherapy.

See “Classification of lung cancers” table.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of lung cancer (e.g., cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, weight loss), and the biopsy shows poorly differentiated, large polygonal tumor cells with abundant cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue, progressive shortness of breath on exertion, and a nonproductive cough. During this time, she also has had intermittent fever and a 5.5-kg (12-lb) weight loss despite no change in appetite. She previously had shortness of breath only during intense exertion, but now it occurs with routine household chores. She has hypothyroidism well controlled with levothyroxine. She lives alone in a three-story house and has no kids. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years and has consumed 4–5 bottles of wine weekly for 10 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, liver function tests, and serum electrolyte concentrations, are within the reference ranges. A serum pregnancy test is negative. An x-ray and CT scan of the chest show multiple large bilateral pulmonary nodules with circumscribed margins predominantly in the upper lobes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is useful in diagnosing thyroid cancer, which may metastasize to the lungs. However, in a patient with multiple large bilateral pulmonary nodules and no clear evidence of a thyroid mass, a different diagnostic test targeted at the most common primary tumor sites is more appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Colorectal, breast, urogenital tract (e.g., renal cell carcinoma), prostate cancer, and melanoma are among the most common primary cancers causing lung metastases. In patients with lung metastases, the diagnostic approach therefore focuses on identifying the primary tumor. Mammography is indicated in all women with lung metastases and cancer of unknown primary. In addition, all patients with lung metastases should receive a CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis with IV contrast.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is useful in diagnosing myeloproliferative neoplasms. These conditions primarily involve the bone marrow and peripheral blood and rarely metastasize to distant organs like the lungs. Therefore, a different diagnostic test is more appropriate at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography is often an appropriate initial diagnostic test for suspected abdominal malignancies, including hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), but HCC rarely metastasizes to the lungs. Additionally, for patients with metastases of unknown origin, a CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis with IV contrast rather than ultrasonography is preferred to screen for abdominopelvic malignancies because of its higher sensitivity. A different diagnostic test is more appropriate at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis is a laboratory study commonly used to diagnose multiple myeloma and other polyclonal gammopathies. Multiple myeloma is characterized by diffuse infiltration of monoclonal plasma cells in the bone marrow and does not typically result in lung metastases. Therefore, a different diagnostic test is more appropriate at this point.
questions.hint: This patient presents with multiple large pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs (cannonball metastases), suggesting lung metastases from an unknown primary tumor.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office for an examination prior to a scheduled cholecystectomy. He works in a glass manufacturing plant. There is no family history of serious illness. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 38 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT-guided biopsy is indicated for a patient who has a solitary lung nodule measuring > 8 mm on a CT scan and has multiple high-risk features (e.g., age > 60 years, history of smoking, occupational carcinogen exposure, family history of lung cancer) or avid uptake on a PET-CT scan. Although this patient has a few high-risk clinical features (e.g., advanced age, smoking history), a different step is indicated before a CT scan or CT-guided biopsy is considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is useful in differentiating intrapulmonary and extrapulmonary causes of restrictive lung disease. This patient's occupational history of glass manufacturing puts him at significant risk for silicosis, which can manifest with a decreased DLCO. Although silicosis can also manifest with solitary lesions, particularly in the upper and middle regions of the lungs, this patient does not have signs of silicosis, such as dyspnea upon exertion, productive cough, or classic x-ray findings (i.e., eggshell calcifications or bilateral ground-glass opacities).

C) CORRECT:

Requesting a previous chest x-ray is the most appropriate first step in the management of a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule, especially when the risk of malignancy is high (age > 60 years, history of smoking). Old imaging studies are used to assess for new changes on the current radiograph (e.g., additional nodules, enlargement). Following the review of previous imaging or if no previous chest x-ray is available, a low-dose CT scan is indicated to assess for nodule size, location, and signs of malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography can be used to evaluate incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodules that are ≥ 8 mm in size with a low or intermediate risk of malignancy. This patient’s nodule does meet the size criteria, but there are factors present that indicate a high risk of malignancy (e.g., age > 60 years, history of smoking). Furthermore, another step in management is indicated first in any patient with an incidental solitary pulmonary nodule on x-ray.

E) INCORRECT:

A repeat x-ray in 12 months is insufficient for this patient who has risk factors for lung cancer and a solitary lung nodule on chest radiograph.
questions.hint: This patient has a peripherally located solitary pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office after a fall on a flight of stairs earlier that day. He slipped, causing him to fall and hit the handrail with the lateral part of his chest. He has no shortness of breath. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but stopped 18 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 126/72 mm Hg. Examination shows normal breath sounds bilaterally. The left lateral chest wall is tender to palpation. An x-ray of the chest shows no fracture; there is a 5-mm lesion in the right upper lung field. There are no previous x-rays of the patient available. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Follow-up x-ray of the chest in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A follow-up chest x-ray is not appropriate for reevaluating an incidental pulmonary nodule because it cannot adequately assess nodule size, appearance, and the presence of other nodules.

B) INCORRECT:

Interferon-γ release assays (IGRAs) are performed in patients with suspected latent tuberculosis infection or reactivation tuberculosis. While tuberculosis (TB) should be considered as a differential diagnosis in patients with a solitary pulmonary nodule, TB-related nodules typically appear as cavitations and calcifications on x-ray. Given this patient's recent visit to a TB-endemic country, active TB should also be considered. However, active TB is unlikely because of the short duration of the trip, the absence of other risk factors (e.g., immunosuppression), and the absence of symptoms (e.g., cough, hemoptysis, fever, night sweats). Regardless, IGRA is not used to diagnose active TB.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

C) CORRECT:

CT scan of the chest is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient, who presents with a 5-mm pulmonary nodule and has no previous x-rays available for comparison. A malignancy risk assessment should be performed based on CT findings and patient characteristics. A CT scan can assess nodule size, appearance (e.g., borders, calcification), and the presence of other nodules more accurately than an x-ray. Radiological factors that increase the risk for malignancy include large nodule size (> 8 mm), location in the upper lung fields, and irregular, spiculated, or scalloped borders. Clinical risk factors for malignancy include age, a history of smoking or asbestos exposure, and a personal or family history of malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance without further evaluation is appropriate for small (≤ 4 mm) incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodules that have a low risk for malignancy. This patient has a 5-mm pulmonary nodule, which needs further evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

The evaluation of an incidental solitary pulmonary nodule involves an assessment of the risk for malignancy. Although histopathological examination of a biopsy taken during bronchoscopy can provide diagnostic information about a pulmonary nodule, this procedure is inappropriate at this time because the risks outweigh the benefits.
questions.hint: This patient has an incidental solitary pulmonary nodule seen on chest x-ray. The most appropriate next step in management requires an assessment of the risk for malignancy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of an incidentally detected pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray. She feels well. She has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 32 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air discloses an oxygen saturation of 94%. CT scan of the chest shows a nodule in the right lung. Which of the following radiographic findings is the strongest predictor for malignancy in this patient's pulmonary mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nodule location is a criterion used to assess the risk of malignancy in patients with solitary pulmonary nodules; however, location in the lower lobe is associated with a low risk of malignancy. Upper lobe location is a high-risk feature.

B) INCORRECT:

Nodule size is a criterion used to assess the risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules. A nodule < 8 mm in size is associated with an intermediate or low risk of malignancy, whereas nodule size > 8–10 mm is considered a high-risk feature.

C) INCORRECT:

Although cavitation can be seen in cavitating lung metastasis, this feature is not specific and therefore not used in the assessment of the risk of malignancy. Inflammatory lung conditions such as lung abscess, sarcoidosis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis can also manifest with cavitation. A different finding is a stronger predictor for malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcification can be seen in some lung cancers, such as pulmonary carcinoid tumors. However, this feature is generally associated with benign conditions such as benign pulmonary hamartomas, which are characterized by popcorn calcifications with alterations of fat. Calcifications can also be seen in tuberculosis or Histoplasma capsulatum-induced infectious granulomas.

E) CORRECT:

The risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules can be determined by clinical evaluation and/or predictive modeling and helps guide management and follow-up. Pulmonary nodules with irregular borders (e.g., scalloped, spiculated) arise due to tumor growth along the pulmonary interstitium and carry a high risk of malignancy. Additional features that indicate a high risk of malignancy include upper lobe location and large nodule size (e.g., > 8–10 mm); older age (e.g. > 60 years), heavy nicotine use, and a history of prior cancer (see “Predictors of malignancy risk in patients with SPNs” table). In high-risk nodules > 8 mm (i.e., comprising only high-risk features) a surgical biopsy should be obtained and treatment should be initiated depending on the results. A PET-CT is indicated for patients with intermediate (i.e., both high and low-risk features) or low-risk nodules (i.e., comprising only low-risk features) > 8 mm. Nodules ≤ 8 mm can be followed up with serial CT scans. Surveillance frequency is determined by the patient's malignancy risk and nodule size.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window)

A spiculated mass (green overlay) is present in the right upper lobe. A small nodule is also visible medial to the mass.
questions.hint: The presence of certain clinical and radiographic features can help determine the risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules and guide further management.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman with a 55-pack-year history of smoking is evaluated for a nodule in the upper lobe of her right lung. On CT imaging, the nodule measures 2.5 cm in diameter (figure). The remainder of the lung parenchyma is normal in appearance, no enlarged lymph nodes are evident, and there are no suspicious liver or adrenal lesions. A full-body positron emission tomography scan reveals that the only metabolically active site is the lung nodule. Brain MRI reveals no abnormalities. Appropriate pulmonary function testing shows no abnormalities. Which of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Sputum stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sputum evaluation for tuberculosis would be of relatively low yield in a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule.

B) INCORRECT:

Transbronchial biopsy of the nodule could yield a diagnosis of cancer, but the nodule would still need to be excised after a positive biopsy. Moreover, when the pre-test probability of malignancy is high, a negative biopsy would not sufficiently rule out malignancy because of the possibility of sampling error, and excision of the nodule would still be recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Sputum cytology would be of relatively low yield in a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with an extensive history of smoking, a pulmonary nodule detected on CT is likely to be malignant if it has a spiculated appearance and measures ≥ 2.3 cm in diameter. If the patient has no contraindication to surgery and there is no evidence of metastatic disease, the most appropriate next step is referral to a thoracic surgeon. Excision of the nodule would enable both treatment and diagnosis of the suspected malignancy.

Key learning point: A patient with an extensive history of smoking and a 2.5-cm, malignant-appearing, solitary pulmonary nodule detected on CT without evidence of metastatic disease on positron emission tomography and brain MRI should be referred for surgical excision of the nodule, provided that the patient has no contraindication to surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

CT-guided biopsy of the nodule could yield a diagnosis of cancer, but the nodule would still need to be excised after a positive biopsy. Moreover, when the pre-test probability of malignancy is high, a negative biopsy would not sufficiently rule out malignancy because of the possibility of sampling error, and excision of the nodule would still be recommended.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-month history of worsening cough and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows wheezing over the right lung fields. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium concentration of 12.5 mg/dL. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lobar pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus or by anaerobes (due to aspiration) can result in a cavitary lesion due to a lung abscess. However, pneumonia is an acute illness that is associated with a fever and a productive cough, unlike this patient who has had a cough for the past 4 months. Also, pneumonia can cause hyponatremia due to SIADH but it does not cause hypercalcemia.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung abscess

A large thick-walled (green overlay) cavity projecting over the perihilar region of the right lung contains an air-fluid level (indicated by red line).

The differential for this appearance includes abscess (bacterial, mycobacterial, fungal), cavitary noninfectious granuloma, and cavitary malignant lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

A cough and weight loss in an older patient with a long history of smoking raise suspicion for lung cancer. Small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is strongly associated with smoking; however, it typically manifests in the proximal bronchi as a central nodule and does not usually form cavitary lesions. Furthermore, SCLC can cause several paraneoplastic syndromes such as Cushing syndrome, SIADH, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, and paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis but it does not cause hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis can cause a cough, weight loss, and a cavitary lesion on x-ray. Severe pulmonary tuberculosis can also result in hypercalcemia. However, cavitary tuberculous lesions typically form in the superior lobes and are often associated with additional symptoms such as fever and night sweats. In this patient with a 35 pack year smoking history and no history of immunocompromise or tuberculosis exposure, a different diagnosis is much more likely.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

D) INCORRECT:

The constellation of pulmonary symptoms, constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss), and hypercalcemia raises suspicion for sarcoidosis. However, a chest x-ray in a patient with sarcoidosis would show coarse reticular opacities and/or bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. The presence of a solitary cavitary lesion suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with sarcoidosis

The pulmonary hila (green overlay) are enlarged and lobulated. Additionally, the right superior mediastinum (red overlay) is widened and dense. A normal thin right paratracheal stripe is not seen.

Relatively symmetric bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph node enlargement on a chest radiograph in sarcoidosis is termed the “1-2-3 sign” or “Garland triad.” Examples of other causes of hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy include lymphoma, metastatic disease, granulomatous infections, and inorganic dust disease.

E) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung is the most common type of lung cancer that develops in smokers and can cause centrally located cavitary lesions as seen in this case. Although paraneoplastic syndromes are generally more common in patients with small cell lung cancer, certain paraneoplastic syndromes such as humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM) primarily arise in association with SCC.
