HHM is caused by the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein, which stimulates PTH receptors and thereby increases bone resorption, renal calcium reabsorption, and phosphate excretion, which results in hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia.
questions.hint: The x-rays show a heterogeneous, irregularly demarcated lesion with a central cavity and air-fluid level in the right middle lobe. Which respiratory pathology can also cause hypercalcemia?

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office because of an episode of coughing with bloody sputum. Over the past 5 months, she has had a persistent nonproductive cough, excessive fatigue, and a 5.6-kg (12.3-lb) weight loss. She does not smoke. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.0-cm nodule with irregular borders at the upper lobe of the left lung. A CT-guided biopsy of the lung nodule is performed. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 15% of all lung cancers. However, small cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral mass that is seen here. In addition, this type of carcinoma is extremely rare in patients who have never smoked.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There are sheets of small, dark blue, cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm (enterochromaffin cells).

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Large cell lung carcinoma is usually found in the periphery, as in this case. However, large cell lung carcinoma only accounts for approximately 5–10% of all lung cancers and is therefore not the most likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchial carcinoid tumors are rare, accounting for 1–2% of all lung cancers. In addition, these tumors typically occur in the central airways, not in the periphery as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 20–25% of all lung cancers. While this type of carcinoma is the most common lung cancer among smokers, only 5% of such cases occur in those who have never smoked. In addition, squamous cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral lesion that is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) CORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer and accounts for approximately 40% of all cases. Additionally, as in this patient, adenocarcinoma is more common in women, is usually found in the periphery, and is the most common lung cancer among those who have never smoked.

Key learning point: Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer, especially in nonsmokers and women, and typically presents as a peripheral lung nodule.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.
questions.hint: This lung cancer subtype is the most common type of pulmonary malignancy overall.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman reports several months of a persistent cough that produces white sputum. One month ago, she noted transient blood streaks in the sputum that developed during an episode of acute bronchitis. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and has a 44-pack-year history. She is otherwise well. A chest x-ray study is obtained (figure). In addition to smoking-cessation counseling, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Complete blood count and coagulation studies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing is useful in evaluating for underlying obstructive or restrictive disease, but these conditions are less likely to manifest with the symptoms described in this case. In addition, such testing would not help establish whether there is a malignancy, which is a much likelier diagnosis in this case.

B) CORRECT:

Lung cancer is the most common malignancy, so it is critical to recognize the nonspecific signs and symptoms in high-risk patients with a history of smoking. Cough is reported by up to 75% of patients who are diagnosed with a pulmonary malignancy. Hemoptysis occurs in up to 50% of patients with a pulmonary malignancy, although bronchitis is the most frequent cause of this symptom. Either of these symptoms could signal an underlying malignancy.

A normal chest x-ray study has <50% sensitivity for detecting early lung cancers. The most appropriate diagnostic test is CT of the chest.

Key learning point: In a patient whose clinical presentation is highly suspicious for lung cancer, the most appropriate diagnostic test is CT of the chest.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating a chest radiograph in 3 months is inappropriate, given its low sensitivity for detecting malignant lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Fiberoptic bronchoscopy can be useful in diagnosing lung cancer, but CT is more appropriate for initial localization of the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count and coagulation studies are unlikely to aid in diagnosis.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 40-pack-year history of cigarette smoking reports 3 months of right shoulder pain that radiates down her arm. Her symptoms have persisted and progressed despite a course of physical therapy and use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications and acetaminophen. On examination, her right shoulder has full range of motion and is not swollen or tender to palpation. She has wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the right hand. Lung examination is remarkable for mild bilateral expiratory wheezing. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve-conduction studies in the right arm are likely to suggest a brachial plexopathy but will not reveal its cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with a significant history of cigarette smoking, the presence of shoulder pain with muscle wasting in the ipsilateral distal extremity and a normal shoulder examination should suggest the possibility of an upper thoracic tumor compressing or invading the brachial plexus. These tumors, called superior pulmonary sulcus or Pancoast tumors, are typically due to non-small-cell lung cancers. The pain that patients experience is due to invasion of the tumor into the brachial plexus or through extension of the tumor into the parietal pleura, ribs, or vertebra. These tumors can also invade the sympathetic chain and inferior cervical ganglion and cause Horner syndrome. The most appropriate next step is to obtain a chest radiograph.

Key learning point: Shoulder pain and wasting of the small muscles of the hand in a patient with a long history of cigarette smoking should prompt evaluation for superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast tumor) with a chest radiograph.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A heterogeneous mass-like opacity (red overlay) in the right apex extends to a thickened irregular pleural surface (blue overlay). Other vague areas of soft tissue density are also present in the right apex (green overlay), and the posterior cortices of the right 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs (indicated by white dashed outlines) are not fully visualized as a result of tumor invasion.

The findings are consistent with a Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine disease can manifest with pain that radiates to the shoulder or radicular neurologic findings in the arm; however, the first priority in this case is to rule out a superior pulmonary sulcus tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with hypertension, insulin-requiring diabetes mellitus, end-stage kidney disease, and a history of cigarette smoking presents with new-onset pain in her right shoulder and weakness in her right hand that have progressed during the past 6 weeks. In addition, she has lost 7 kg (15 lb) during the past 4 months. Physical examination reveals a unilateral, right-sided ptosis with a pinpoint pupil of the right eye, as well as muscle atrophy, hand weakness, and numbness in the fourth and fifth fingers of the right hand. Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis leads to renal insufficiency and can cause sensorimotor neuropathy but is not associated with the development of Horner syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Although myasthenia gravis can cause ptosis and muscle weakness, it is not associated with miosis (a component of Horner syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

Although carotid artery dissection could progress to stroke and subsequently cause arm weakness, this event would likely occur more acutely than the gradual development of Horner syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Tumors of the superior pulmonary sulcus, also called Pancoast tumors, can cause a classic presentation by compressing against nerve structures as they pass through or near the thoracic inlet. Compression of the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots can cause pain and neurologic compromise of those nerves. In addition, interruption of the sympathetic nerve chain running to the head can result in Horner syndrome, which is characterized by unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis. Treatment of superior pulmonary sulcus tumors involves multidisciplinary care coordinated among a thoracic surgeon, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist.

Key learning point: The gradual development of arm weakness and Horner syndrome in an older patient with a history of cigarette smoking is most indicative of a diagnosis of a superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Arm weakness and numbness in the fingers is more consistent with a dermatomal distribution than with a brainstem lesion.
questions.hint: Ipsilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis indicate Horner syndrome, a constellation of symptoms secondary to compression of the cervical sympathetic ganglion.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremity is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with muscle weakness and may rarely be associated with dysautonomia. However, muscle weakness typically is asymmetric and would not improve with exercise, but show a progressive course. Since both upper and lower motor neurons are affected in ALS, additional symptoms such as hyperreflexia, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness would be expected.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

B) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) may cause lower limb muscle weakness. However, symptoms typically worsen throughout the day and with exercise as opposed to this patient's improvement of symptoms upon repetitive stimulation. MG classically manifests with weakness of the extraocular muscles causing ptosis and/or diplopia, whereas deep tendon reflexes and autonomic functions are unaffected. Moreover, MG is not associated with lung cancer, but with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis manifests with proximal muscle weakness. However, symptoms are typically progressive and would not improve with exercise. Although dermatomyositis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer, cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron papules and a heliotrope rash would also be expected. Moreover, dermatomyositis is not associated with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, it would usually be associated with other symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Weight loss as seen in this patient would be unusual. Hypothyroidism is not associated with lung cancer.

E) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody
questions.hint: This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman has a 30-pack-year history of smoking and continues to smoke daily. She does not take any medications. A review of her systems is unremarkable. She had a normal colonoscopy 5 years ago, an unremarkable chest radiograph and mammogram 6 months ago, and a normal Pap test 6 months ago. Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Low-dose helical CT of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian ultrasound screenings are not proven to reduce cancer mortality.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the breasts is not warranted in a patient with a recent normal mammography and no suspicion for genetic susceptibility to breast cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat colonoscopy and fecal occult-blood testing are not indicated in a patient with a normal colonoscopy within the past 5 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat colonoscopy and fecal occult-blood testing are not indicated in a patient with a normal colonoscopy within the past 5 years.

E) CORRECT:

The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends annual screening for lung cancer in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20-pack-year history of cigarette smoking and either currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. The preferred screening method is low-dose helical CT of the chest rather than a single chest radiograph or annual chest radiography. In one large study, CT-screened patients had a 20% relative reduction in lung cancer-related mortality, compared with unscreened patients.

Key learning point: In patients aged 50 to 80 years who either currently smoke or have a history of heavy smoking (>20 pack-years), lung cancer screening should be conducted using low-dose helical CT of the chest.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and weakness for the past 5 days. During this period, she has had a headache that worsens when she leans forward or lies down. Her arms and face have appeared swollen over the past 2 weeks. She has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent radical amputation of the left breast followed by radiation therapy 4 years ago. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows jugular venous distention, a mastectomy scar over the left thorax, and engorged veins on the anterior chest wall. There is 1+ pitting edema in both arms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While Hodgkin lymphomas frequently manifest with mediastinal lymphadenopathy, compression of the SVC resulting in SVC syndrome is rare. Non-Hodgkin lymphomas, on the other hand, are responsible for the majority of cases of SVC syndrome in young patients. This patient lacks any typical symptoms of lymphoma (painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or B symptoms), which makes a malignant lymphoma unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of breast cancer, chronic smoking, and tamoxifen therapy increases the risk of a hypercoagulable state and the development of a pulmonary embolism (PE). PE may cause right heart failure (i.e., jugular venous distension, hypotension, tachycardia) but not selective facial and upper limb edema. In addition, and in contrast to this patient's features, PE manifests with respiratory distress, cough, and rales on pulmonary auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is a predisposing factor for the development of constrictive pericarditis, which may be the underlying cause of this patient's jugular venous distension and peripheral edema. However, patients with constrictive pericarditis typically have a thickened myocardium and a pericardial knock on auscultation, which is not heard here. Additionally, the peripheral edema in constrictive pericarditis involves both the upper and lower extremities; the presence of a selective facial and upper limb edema in this patient suggests another etiology.

D) CORRECT:

SVC syndrome is most commonly caused by lung cancer (usually small cell lung cancer or squamous cell carcinoma) or non-Hodgkin lymphoma (particularly in younger patients). This patient's history of chronic smoking is a risk factor for lung cancer. Compression of the SVC by a tumor impairs the venous backflow to the right atrium, resulting in venous congestion in the head, neck, and upper extremities. Other nonmalignant causes of SVC syndrome include mediastinal fibrosis, tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, or thrombosis of the SVC due to the placement of a central venous device. A CT scan of the chest should be obtained in this patient to evaluate for malignancy.
Image Description:

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is caused by obstruction of the SVC (e.g., due to malignancy or intraluminal thrombosis), resulting in impaired blood flow from the SVC into the right atrium. As a consequence, drainage occurs increasingly into the inferior vena cava via collateral veins, resulting in a prominent venous patterning on the upper body. Venous congestion proximally to the obstruction results in edema of the upper extremities, neck, and face.

SVC syndrome can become life-threatening if cerebral edema (leading to increased intracranial pressure) or laryngeal edema develop.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrotic syndrome causes renal filtration dysfunction and is characterized by marked edema, weight gain, hypertension, and a hypercoagulable state. This patient has a selective facial and upper limb edema, which is not characteristic of the edema pattern seen in nephrotic syndrome (initially a periorbital and later general edema). Additionally, nephrotic syndrome does not explain this patient's JVD, tachycardia, and hypotension.
questions.hint: Headache that worsens when leaning forward, engorged veins over the anterior chest, and swelling limited to the head, neck, and upper extremities are consistent with superior vena cava syndrome (SVC syndrome).

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with three months of progressive shortness of breath, persistent dry cough, easy fatigability, and unintentional 8-lb weight loss. He denies hemoptysis or fever. He has a 45-year pack-year smoking history. Examination shows mild clubbing and decreased air entry over the right lower lung zone. Basic labs show mild anemia (see report).
Imaging: Peripheral lesion in the right lower lobe
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bacterial pneumonia typically presents acutely with fever, productive cough, and chills, and radiographically shows lobar consolidation or diffuse infiltrates. The patient's chronic symptoms and weight loss suggest a chronic process, not the acute presentation of bacterial pneumonia. The absence of fever and the presence of a peripheral lesion further reduce the likelihood of bacterial pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary tuberculosis typically presents with fever, night sweats, and a productive cough, often with hemoptysis. Radiologically, it usually involves upper lobe cavitary lesions. The absence of fever and hemoptysis, along with a peripheral lesion in the right lower lobe, makes tuberculosis unlikely. Furthermore, smoking is not a risk factor for tuberculosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation, including a long history of smoking, unintentional weight loss, and digital clubbing, aligns with lung large cell carcinoma. The imaging reveals a peripheral lesion in the right lower lobe, a common site for large cell carcinoma, which often originates in the peripheral lung parenchyma. The chronic symptoms of progressive shortness of breath and persistent dry cough are consistent with the insidious nature of peripheral lung cancers. Additionally, mild anemia suggests a systemic process, possibly due to malignant paraneoplastic or inflammatory effects.

Key learning point: In a patient with a significant smoking history and symptoms of shortness of breath, dry cough, fatigue, and rapid weight loss, lung cancer should be highly suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis often affects younger individuals and presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse reticulonodular patterns on imaging. The solitary peripheral lesion in the right lower lobe and the patient's age and smoking history do not align with sarcoidosis. Additionally, there are no extrathoracic manifestations such as erythema nodosum or uveitis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea over five months and unintentional weight loss. He has a 50 pack-year smoking history. He has swelling and tenderness around his wrists and ankles and physical examination shows digital clubbing. He has a mild chronic cough but no wheezing or orthopnea (see reports).

Pulmonary function tests: Mild irreversible obstructive pattern
CT scan of the chest: 3-cm right hilar mass with no obvious lymphadenopathy

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis, common in smokers, presents with cough, mucus production, and obstructive pattern on pulmonary function tests. This patient's unintentional weight loss, digital clubbing, and hilar mass suggest a neoplastic process rather than chronic bronchitis.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's significant smoking history, progressive dyspnea, weight loss, and the presence of a hilar mass suggest bronchogenic carcinoma. Lung cancers can cause digital clubbing through paraneoplastic mechanisms, involving the release of growth factors like vascular endothelial growth factor, which promote periosteal new bone formation and soft tissue proliferation.

Key learning point: Hilar mass, unintentional weight loss, and hypertrophic osteoarthropathy in a patient with a long history of smoking should raise concern for bronchogenic carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Asthma is characterized by reversible airway obstruction and episodic symptoms, not persistent ones. Digital clubbing is rare in asthma and more associated with conditions involving hypoxemia or paraneoplastic mechanisms. The patient's age, smoking history, and imaging findings suggest a different etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary tuberculosis can cause weight loss and chronic cough, but typically presents with cavitary lesions and lymphadenopathy on imaging, not an isolated hilar mass. The patient's age, smoking history, and imaging findings suggest a different etiology.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with a three-month history of cough producing blood-tinged sputum. Over the past two weeks, he has also noted hoarseness, chest discomfort, and swelling and tenderness around his wrists and ankles. He has a 40-year pack history of cigarette smoking. Examination shows pronounced digital clubbing (see report).
Chest X-ray: Ill-defined mass in the right upper lobe
Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms and findings indicative of primary lung cancer, including a chronic cough with blood-tinged sputum, chest discomfort, and hoarseness. The pronounced digital clubbing and joint swelling suggest hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with lung cancer. The chest X-ray reveals an ill-defined mass in the right upper lobe, further supporting the diagnosis of bronchogenic carcinoma. The patient's significant smoking history increases the likelihood of a pulmonary neoplasm.

Key learning point: In a heavy smoker with hemoptysis, chest pain, voice changes, and digital clubbing, bronchogenic carcinoma should be highly suspected, especially when accompanied by signs of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary tuberculosis often presents with cavitary lesions or patchy consolidations, not an ill-defined mass. Constitutional symptoms like fever and weight loss are common in TB but absent here. The digital clubbing and joint tenderness suggest a paraneoplastic syndrome, more typical of lung cancer. The patient's smoking history further supports a neoplastic etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Hoarseness is a symptom of laryngeal carcinoma, but the chronic cough, blood-tinged sputum, and right upper lobe mass suggest a pulmonary origin. Digital clubbing and joint swelling indicate hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, commonly linked to lung cancer. The patient's smoking history and overall clinical picture align more with a lung neoplasm than a laryngeal lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis typically presents with a productive cough and purulent sputum, along with imaging showing dilated bronchi. The ill-defined mass on chest X-ray and systemic symptoms like hoarseness and joint swelling are inconsistent with bronchiectasis. The patient's smoking history and paraneoplastic features suggest a neoplastic process rather than chronic airway infection.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man is seen for a routine check-up. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and well-controlled type 2 diabetes. He has no respiratory complaints. He is uncertain if he has ever had prior chest imaging. Physical examination is normal, and vital signs are stable (see report).
Chest X-ray: 1.2-cm nodule in the left upper lung field
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this nodule?

choices.text: Locate previous imaging or obtain a chest CT if none is available
Refer for PET scan to assess metabolic activity
Proceed with bronchoscopy and tissue biopsy of the nodule
Advise surgical resection without additional imaging

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Evaluating a pulmonary nodule involves assessing its stability over time, which is best achieved by comparing current imaging with previous studies. Stability suggests a benign process, while growth raises concern for malignancy, especially in patients with risk factors like a long smoking history. If previous imaging is unavailable, a high-resolution chest CT is the next step. CT provides detailed assessment of the nodule's size, shape, margins, and internal characteristics, including calcification patterns, aiding in risk stratification. It also detects additional findings in the lung parenchyma or mediastinum that may influence management.

Key learning point: For an incidental pulmonary nodule found on chest X-ray, the next best step is to review old imaging to assess for changes, and if unavailable or inconclusive, proceed with a CT chest with IV contrast for further characterization.

B) INCORRECT:

FDG-PET scanning evaluates metabolic activity of pulmonary nodules, distinguishing benign from malignant processes. However, initial evaluation of an incidentally discovered nodule should begin with a high-resolution CT scan to delineate anatomical details like margins, density, and calcifications, which are crucial for risk stratification. CT imaging is warranted before metabolic evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy with tissue biopsy is not recommended as an initial step without further imaging. A high-resolution CT scan is essential to gather detailed information about the nodule’s size, morphology, and location. CT evaluation informs whether the lesion has features associated with malignancy and is amenable to bronchoscopic access. Bronchoscopy has limited yield for small or peripheral nodules and carries procedural risks.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection requires a high suspicion of malignancy substantiated by detailed imaging and risk stratification. The 1.2-cm nodule detected on a plain radiograph lacks information about margin characteristics, density, or calcification, which a high-resolution CT scan would provide. Immediate surgical resection without further noninvasive workup is overly aggressive in an asymptomatic, stable patient.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is referred for routine follow-up. He quit smoking 10 years ago and has a 12-pack-year smoking history. He has no cough, shortness of breath, or weight loss. He has no personal or family history of lung cancer. Physical examination is normal. Basic laboratory tests are within normal limits (see report).
Low-dose screening chest CT: Solitary 6 mm noncalcified nodule in the right upper lobe with well-defined margins and no associated lymphadenopathy
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat low-dose chest CT scan in 3 to 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

PET scans are less effective for small nodules like this 6-mm lesion due to limited spatial resolution, increasing the risk of false negatives. The patient's low-risk profile, including a modest smoking history and lack of symptoms or concerning imaging features, supports a conservative approach with follow-up CT rather than immediate PET scanning.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical resection is considered for highly suspicious lesions. However, a 6-mm nodule with well-defined margins and no lymphadenopathy in a low-risk patient has a low malignancy probability. Surgical resection carries significant risks and is not justified given the benign-appearing imaging findings. Guidelines recommend serial imaging for small nodules in low-risk individuals.

C) CORRECT:

A solitary 6-mm noncalcified nodule with well-defined margins in a patient with a minimal smoking history suggests a low risk of malignancy. Serial imaging is preferred over invasive procedures to monitor for changes in nodule size, which can indicate malignancy. A follow-up CT in 3 to 6 months allows for assessment of interval growth, a key indicator of neoplastic processes, while minimizing radiation exposure and unnecessary risks. Stable nodules typically indicate benign processes, and guidelines support a conservative approach when the lesion lacks worrisome features like spiculation or lymphadenopathy.

Key learning point: In asymptomatic patients with a small lung lesion (<8 mm) and low risk of malignancy, surveillance with a repeat CT scan in 3-6 months is recommended over immediate invasive procedures.

D) INCORRECT:

CT-guided biopsy is invasive and typically reserved for lesions with high suspicion of malignancy. A 6-mm nodule poses technical challenges for biopsy due to its size, resulting in lower diagnostic yield. The nodule's well-defined margins and absence of spiculated edges or lymphadenopathy, combined with the patient's modest smoking history, suggest a low cancer probability, making biopsy unnecessary at this time.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents for a routine evaluation. He is asymptomatic, exercises regularly, and has no respiratory complaints. He has no significant past medical history, has never smoked, and denies occupational exposures. Physical examination is normal. Pulmonary function tests are within normal limits. Laboratory results, including complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and lactate dehydrogenase, are within normal ranges. An abdominal CT scan obtained to evaluate mild right flank pain incidentally identifies a 6 mm solitary pulmonary nodule in the right lower lobe (see report).
Chest CT: Well-circumscribed, non-calcified lesion without suspicious features
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical resection is for nodules with a high probability of malignancy. The 6 mm nodule lacks suspicious features, and the patient has a low-risk profile, making surgical intervention unwarranted. Noninvasive follow-up with periodic imaging is appropriate for small, incidental nodules in low-risk individuals.

B) INCORRECT:

PET scans are used for larger nodules with suspicious features due to their ability to detect increased metabolic activity. However, a 6 mm nodule is below the reliable detection threshold for PET imaging. The patient's low risk for lung cancer and the nodule's non-suspicious CT characteristics make a PET scan unlikely to provide useful information.

C) INCORRECT:

CT-guided needle biopsy is reserved for larger nodules with concerning features. The 6 mm nodule in this low-risk patient lacks suspicious characteristics, making invasive biopsy unnecessary. The procedure carries risks such as pneumothorax and bleeding, which are not justified given the low likelihood of malignancy.

D) CORRECT:

In an asymptomatic, low-risk patient, a 6 mm solitary pulmonary nodule without high-risk radiologic features is best managed with follow-up imaging. Guidelines, such as those from the Fleischner Society, recommend a repeat chest CT in 6–12 months to assess for interval growth. This approach minimizes unnecessary radiation exposure and avoids risks associated with invasive procedures. The nodule's well-circumscribed appearance and absence of calcification support a conservative management strategy.

Key learning point: For small pulmonary nodules (less than 8 mm) in low-risk patients, observation with regular follow-up imaging is the most appropriate management strategy to monitor for changes without unnecessary invasive procedures.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man undergoes chest imaging for routine evaluation of mild dyspnea. He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and no significant occupational exposures. He denies cough, hemoptysis, or weight loss. Physical examination and basic labs are normal (see report).
Chest imaging: Solitary 7-mm nodule with smooth, well-defined borders in the right upper lobe
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat chest CT in 3 to 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT-guided biopsy is for nodules with high malignancy suspicion. A 7-mm nodule with smooth borders increases false-negative biopsy risk and carries procedural risks like pneumothorax. Without high-risk features or significant smoking history, serial imaging is a more appropriate, noninvasive strategy.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is for nodules with strong malignancy indicators, such as larger size or irregular borders. This 7-mm nodule has benign features and a low cancer probability due to minimal smoking history and lack of symptoms. Surgery's potential morbidity is not justified, making follow-up imaging a better approach.

C) INCORRECT:

PET scans are typically used for lesions 8-10 mm or larger due to better detection of metabolic activity. This 7-mm nodule may not accumulate enough FDG for a definitive signal, risking false negatives. The smooth borders and modest smoking history suggest a benign process, reducing the utility of a PET scan.

D) CORRECT:

A solitary pulmonary nodule (SPN) is a well-circumscribed opacity in the lung. Management depends on size, risk factors, and imaging characteristics. This 7-mm nodule with smooth borders and a modest smoking history suggests a low malignancy risk. Guidelines recommend serial imaging for such nodules, as the cancer risk is minimal. Repeat CT in 3 to 6 months assesses for growth or changes, avoiding unnecessary risks from PET scans or invasive procedures, which are reserved for higher-risk lesions.

Key learning point: For a solitary pulmonary nodule with low to moderate risk factors for malignancy, such as a small size and sharp borders, a follow-up CT in 3-6 months is recommended to monitor for changes.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with mild dyspnea on exertion and intermittent hemoptysis for three weeks. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history. A chest CT scan reveals a 2.5 cm spiculated mass in the right upper lobe without significant lymphadenopathy or evidence of metastatic disease. Bronchoscopy with biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination shows mild wheezing and an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. His complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are normal. He is referred to a thoracic surgeon for possible resection (see reports).
He inquires about further evaluations needed to ensure surgical tolerance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating his candidacy for resection?

choices.text: Perform mediastinoscopy with lymph node biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is considered for locally advanced lung cancer to downstage tumors. This patient has a 2.5 cm mass without lymphadenopathy or metastasis, indicating early-stage disease. The focus is on evaluating cardiopulmonary reserve, not systemic therapy, as there is no evidence of locally advanced disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Mediastinoscopy with lymph node biopsy is used to evaluate mediastinal lymph node involvement for cancer staging. The chest CT scan shows no significant lymphadenopathy, and the focus is on assessing surgical tolerance, not further oncologic staging. Pulmonary function assessments are more relevant for evaluating surgical risk.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with lung cancer and a significant smoking history, pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are essential to assess respiratory reserve before resection. PFTs, including forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO), provide data on ventilatory capacity and gas exchange efficiency. These measurements help predict postoperative pulmonary complications and guide surgical planning, ensuring the patient can tolerate lung parenchyma reduction.

Key learning point: In patients with resectable lung cancer, pulmonary function tests are essential to assess surgical candidacy, especially in those with a history of smoking.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical resection may seem appropriate for early-stage squamous cell carcinoma. However, the patient's 45-pack-year smoking history and mild dyspnea necessitate a detailed evaluation of cardiopulmonary reserve. Oxygen saturation alone does not fully assess pulmonary function, and skipping this evaluation could increase postoperative complication risk.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with a three-month history of progressive cough, occasional hemoptysis, and a 6-kg weight loss to the Outpatient Clinic. He has a 35-year smoking history and experiences mild shortness of breath on exertion. He denies fever, night sweats, or chills. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds in the right upper zone. Laboratory tests show a normal white cell count and normal CRP. A sputum culture yields no growth of typical pathogens (see reports).

Chest X-ray: Persistent right upper lobe consolidation unchanged after antibiotics
Bronchoalveolar lavage: Atypical epithelial cells

Which of the following diagnoses best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Organizing pneumonia can present with nonresolving consolidations and subacute symptoms, but typically shows elevated inflammatory markers. The patient's significant weight loss, smoking history, and hemoptysis are more indicative of a neoplastic process. Atypical epithelial cells on bronchoalveolar lavage suggest malignancy rather than organizing pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

A lung abscess often presents with productive cough, foul-smelling sputum, and cavitary lesions on imaging, along with elevated inflammatory markers. This patient has normal laboratory markers, no fever, and imaging shows persistent consolidation without cavitation. Atypical epithelial cells on bronchoalveolar lavage suggest a neoplastic process, not an infection.

C) CORRECT:

This patient, with a significant smoking history, presents with symptoms such as progressive cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, which are characteristic of lung cancer. The persistent right upper lobe consolidation on imaging, unchanged after antibiotics, and normal inflammatory markers suggest a non-infectious etiology. The presence of atypical epithelial cells on bronchoalveolar lavage indicates malignant transformation within the bronchial epithelium, supporting a diagnosis of bronchogenic carcinoma.

Key learning point: A persistent dense area of consolidation in the lung that does not respond to antibiotics, along with atypical cells in bronchioalveolar lavage, is suggestive of bronchogenic cancer.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung cancer

An irregularly marginated mass-like opacity (green overlay) is present in the right upper lobe.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary tuberculosis typically presents with chronic cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss, but is often accompanied by fever, night sweats, and cavitary lesions on imaging. This patient lacks these constitutional symptoms, and the normal white cell count and C-reactive protein further argue against an active infectious process like tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a 30-pack-year smoking history comes to your clinic for follow-up, 6 months after a chest CT revealed a solitary 5-mm solid nodule in the upper lobe of the right lung. Repeat CT now shows the nodule has increased to 2 cm, with involvement of ipsilateral mediastinal lymph nodes. Biopsy of the pulmonary nodule demonstrates small, dark blue tumor cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Cranial MRI and skeletal scintigraphy show no evidence of other metastases. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The combination of polychemotherapy (with cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation therapy is the treatment of choice for small cell lung cancer (SCLC) in patients with limited-stage disease. Individuals with limited-stage SCLC should receive treatment with curative intent. SCLC is usually unresectable and surgery is only considered in limited-stage disease with very small lesions and no evidence of nodal involvement (N0). This patient has N1 SCLC.

SCLCs initially respond very well to chemotherapy, but remission only lasts for a short period of time. Prophylactic cranial irradiation is used to prevent the occurrence of brain metastases in patients with SCLC who have responded to initial chemotherapy. The average 5-year survival rate of patients with limited-stage SCLC is 10–15%.

Key learning point: Limited-stage small cell lung cancer is treated with combined chemotherapy (cisplatin-etoposide) and radiotherapy, as surgery is generally not indicated when there is nodal involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Lobectomy for lung cancer is usually reserved for patients who have non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). SCLC is typically unresectable and surgery is only considered in limited-stage disease in which there are very small lesions and no evidence of nodal involvement or distant metastases. This patient has N1 SCLC.

C) INCORRECT:

Targeted therapy with EGFR inhibitors (e.g., gefitinib) is indicated in patients with EGFR-positive, advanced-stage non-small cell lung cancer. This patient, however, has SCLC, which requires a different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

While radiation therapy is typically part of the initial treatment for limited-stage SCLC, radiation alone is not the mainstay of treatment and is not curative.

E) INCORRECT:

Wedge resection for lung cancer is generally reserved for patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who cannot tolerate a lobectomy (e.g., patients with poor pulmonary function or comorbidities). SCLC is usually unresectable, and surgery is only considered in limited-stage disease with very small lesions and no evidence of nodal involvement. This patient has N1 SCLC.
questions.hint: This biopsy shows small cell lung cancer (SCLC). This patient has no evidence of distant spread beyond mediastinal lymph nodes, meaning he has N1 limited-stage SCLC.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of increasing pain, swelling, and stiffness in both ankles. She reports that the pain and stiffness worsen with movement. She has no history of serious illnesses and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 36.8ºC. On examination, she has digital clubbing. The ankle joints are swollen and tender to palpation, and range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the lower extremities shows periosteal thickening of the distal tibial diaphysis in both extremities. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Accelerated bone turnover is the cause of Paget disease of bone (PDB), which often affects the long bones of the lower extremities (e.g., tibia). PDB can manifest with bone pain, swelling overlying the affected region, and periosteal thickening. However, PDB typically does not lead to arthritis, and in addition to a periosteal reaction, an x-ray would show lytic and/or sclerotic lesions in the bone cortex and, possibly, anterior bowing of the tibia. This patient's condition is not the result of accelerated bone turnover.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis is a chronic degenerative disease that can affect the ankle joints and manifests with joint stiffness, restricted range of motion, and pain that worsens with activity. However, osteoarthritis does not cause digital clubbing or periosteal thickening. Instead, an x-ray would show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and/or subchondral cysts. This patient's condition is not the result of a chronic degenerative process.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune joint disease that occasionally affects the ankle joints, and manifests with joint pain, swelling, and decreased range of motion. However, the stiffness and pain associated with RA typically improve rather than worsen with activity. Moreover, RA does not cause digital clubbing or periosteal thickening; instead, finger deformities (e.g., swan neck deformity, Boutonniere deformity) and different x-ray findings (e.g., concentric joint space narrowing, subcortical cysts, para-articular osteopenia) would be expected. This patient's arthralgia is not the result of an autoimmune process.

D) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (HOA) is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma of the lung. Patients with HOA present with arthritis, digital clubbing, and periostitis of the distal diaphysis of long bones, as seen here. Some affected individuals also develop thickening of the skin (pachyderma). The exact pathophysiology of this condition is not entirely understood but the release of certain growth factors like VEGF and PDGF from the tumor is thought to play a role. Other causes include chronic pulmonary conditions (e.g., bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis) and, less commonly, hepatic and gastrointestinal disease (e.g., cirrhosis, inflammatory bowel disease). HOA in a previously healthy patient should raise suspicion for occult pulmonary malignancy and a low-dose CT scan of the chest should be obtained. Adenocarcinoma of the lung can occur in nonsmokers, like this patient, and is more common among female than male individuals.

In rare cases, HOA occurs as a result of a hereditary disorder (primary HOA).

Key learning point: Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy—characterized by digital clubbing, periostitis, and joint symptoms—is most often a paraneoplastic manifestation of occult pulmonary malignancy, especially lung adenocarcinoma.
Image Description:

X-ray ankle (left: AP view; right: lateral view)

Smooth periosteal reaction (green overlay) has developed primarily along the distal metaphyses of the tibia and fibula.

This appearance is characteristic of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

A right-to-left cardiac or pulmonary shunt (e.g., pulmonary arteriovenous malformation) rather than a left-to-right cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale) can cause hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. A right-to-left shunt bypasses the filtering effect of pulmonary circulation on platelet clumps, which then accumulate peripherally and produce growth factors (e.g., PDGF) that can cause osseous hypertrophy.
questions.hint: This patient has hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, which is due to distal hyperemia and proliferation of connective tissue in the distal parts of extremities, especially the fingers.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to your clinic for a preoperative examination prior to a scheduled cholecystectomy. He works in a glass manufacturing plant. There is no family history of serious illness. He has a 38-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes daily. Vital signs are normal. Examination is normal. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. A chest x-ray is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT-guided biopsy is indicated for a patient who has a solitary lung nodule measuring > 8 mm on a CT scan and has multiple high-risk features (e.g., age > 60 years, history of smoking, occupational carcinogen exposure, family history of lung cancer) or avid uptake on a PET-CT scan. Although this patient has a few high-risk clinical features (e.g., advanced age, smoking history), a different step is indicated before a CT scan or CT-guided biopsy is considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography can be used to evaluate incidental solitary solid pulmonary nodules that are ≥ 8 mm in size with a low or intermediate risk of malignancy. This patient’s nodule does meet the size criteria, but there are factors present that indicate a high risk of malignancy (e.g., age > 60 years, history of smoking). Furthermore, another step in management is indicated first in any patient with an incidental solitary pulmonary nodule on x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

A repeat x-ray in 12 months is insufficient for this patient who has risk factors for lung cancer and a solitary lung nodule on chest radiograph.

D) INCORRECT:

Diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is useful in differentiating intrapulmonary and extrapulmonary causes of restrictive lung disease. This patient's occupational history of glass manufacturing puts him at significant risk for silicosis, which can manifest with a decreased DLCO. Although silicosis can also manifest with solitary lesions, particularly in the upper and middle regions of the lungs, this patient does not have signs of silicosis, such as dyspnea upon exertion, productive cough, or classic x-ray findings (i.e., eggshell calcifications or bilateral ground-glass opacities).

E) CORRECT:

Requesting a previous chest x-ray is the most appropriate first step in the management of a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule, especially when the risk of malignancy is high (age > 60 years, history of smoking). Old imaging studies are used to assess for new changes on the current radiograph (e.g., additional nodules, enlargement). Following the review of previous imaging or if no previous chest x-ray is available, a low-dose CT scan is indicated to assess for nodule size, location, and signs of malignancy.

Key learning point: The initial step in evaluating a solitary pulmonary nodule is to compare with previous chest x-rays to assess for stability or changes before proceeding with further imaging or intervention.
questions.hint: This patient has a peripherally located solitary pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of worsening cough and a 4.5-kg weight loss. She has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On examination, there is wheezing over the right lung fields. Laboratory studies show a serum calcium concentration of 3.1 mmol/L (2.12–2.52). Chest x-rays are provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung is the most common type of lung cancer that develops in smokers and can cause centrally located cavitary lesions as seen in this case. Although paraneoplastic syndromes are generally more common in patients with small cell lung cancer, certain paraneoplastic syndromes such as humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM) primarily arise in association with SCC. HHM is caused by the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein, which stimulates PTH receptors and thereby increases bone resorption, renal calcium reabsorption, and phosphate excretion, which results in hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia.

Key learning point: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is strongly associated with smoking, often presents as a central cavitary lesion, and can cause hypercalcemia via parathyroid hormone-related protein secretion.

B) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis can cause a cough, weight loss, and a cavitary lesion on x-ray. Severe pulmonary tuberculosis can also result in hypercalcemia. However, cavitary tuberculous lesions typically form in the superior lobes and are often associated with additional symptoms such as fever and night sweats. In this patient with a 35 pack year smoking history and no history of immunocompromise or tuberculosis exposure, a different diagnosis is much more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Lobar pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus aureus or by anaerobes (due to aspiration) can result in a cavitary lesion due to a lung abscess. However, pneumonia is an acute illness that is associated with a fever and a productive cough, unlike this patient who has had a cough for the past 4 months. Also, pneumonia can cause hyponatremia due to SIADH but it does not cause hypercalcemia.

D) INCORRECT:

A cough and weight loss in an older patient with a long history of smoking raise suspicion for lung cancer. Small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is strongly associated with smoking; however, it typically manifests in the proximal bronchi as a central nodule and does not usually form cavitary lesions. Furthermore, SCLC can cause several paraneoplastic syndromes such as Cushing syndrome, SIADH, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, and paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis but it does not cause hypercalcemia.

E) INCORRECT:

The constellation of pulmonary symptoms, constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss), and hypercalcemia raises suspicion for sarcoidosis. However, a chest x-ray in a patient with sarcoidosis would show coarse reticular opacities and/or bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. The presence of a solitary cavitary lesion suggests a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: The x-rays show a heterogeneous, irregularly demarcated lesion with a central cavity and air-fluid level in the right middle lobe. Which respiratory pathology can also cause hypercalcemia?

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of an episode of coughing with bloody sputum. She reports a persistent nonproductive cough, excessive fatigue, and a 5.6-kg weight loss over the past 5 months. She does not smoke. A chest x-ray shows a 2.0-cm nodule with irregular borders in the upper lobe of the left lung. You perform a CT-guided biopsy of the lung nodule. Pathologic examination of the biopsy specimen is most likely to show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 15% of all lung cancers. However, small cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral mass that is seen here. In addition, this type of carcinoma is extremely rare in patients who have never smoked.

B) INCORRECT:

Large cell lung carcinoma is usually found in the periphery, as in this case. However, large cell lung carcinoma only accounts for approximately 5–10% of all lung cancers and is therefore not the most likely diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer and accounts for approximately 40% of all cases. Additionally, as in this patient, adenocarcinoma is more common in women, is usually found in the periphery, and is the most common lung cancer among those who have never smoked.

Key learning point: Adenocarcinoma is the most common lung cancer, especially in nonsmokers and women, and typically presents as a peripheral lung nodule.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial carcinoid tumors are rare, accounting for 1–2% of all lung cancers. In addition, these tumors typically occur in the central airways, not in the periphery as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell lung carcinoma is common, accounting for approximately 20–25% of all lung cancers. While this type of carcinoma is the most common lung cancer among smokers, only 5% of such cases occur in those who have never smoked. In addition, squamous cell lung carcinoma typically occurs in the central airways and is seen as a hilar mass on chest x-ray, unlike the peripheral lesion that is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This lung cancer subtype is the most common type of pulmonary malignancy overall.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to your clinic with several months of persistent cough producing white sputum. One month ago, she noticed transient blood streaks in her sputum during an episode of acute bronchitis. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and has a 44-pack-year history. A chest x-ray is obtained (figure). In addition to smoking-cessation counseling, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Complete blood count and coagulation studies.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fiberoptic bronchoscopy can be useful in diagnosing lung cancer, but CT is more appropriate for initial localization of the lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing is useful in evaluating for underlying obstructive or restrictive disease, but these conditions are less likely to manifest with the symptoms described in this case. In addition, such testing would not help establish whether there is a malignancy, which is a much likelier diagnosis in this case.

C) CORRECT:

Lung cancer is the most common malignancy, so it is critical to recognize the nonspecific signs and symptoms in high-risk patients with a history of smoking. Cough is reported by up to 75% of patients who are diagnosed with a pulmonary malignancy. Hemoptysis occurs in up to 50% of patients with a pulmonary malignancy, although bronchitis is the most frequent cause of this symptom. Either of these symptoms could signal an underlying malignancy.

A normal chest x-ray study has <50% sensitivity for detecting early lung cancers. The most appropriate diagnostic test is CT of the chest.

Key learning point: In a patient whose clinical presentation is highly suspicious for lung cancer, the most appropriate diagnostic test is CT of the chest.

D) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count and coagulation studies are unlikely to aid in diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeating a chest radiograph in 3 months is inappropriate, given its low sensitivity for detecting malignant lesions.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a 40-pack-year smoking history comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of right shoulder pain radiating down her arm. Her symptoms have persisted and worsened despite physical therapy, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, and acetaminophen. On examination, her right shoulder has full range of motion and is not swollen or tender to palpation. There is wasting of the intrinsic muscles of her right hand. Lung examination reveals mild bilateral expiratory wheezing. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve-conduction studies in the right arm are likely to suggest a brachial plexopathy but will not reveal its cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs or MRI of the right shoulder are unlikely to be helpful, given the normal shoulder examination and the neurologic findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical spine disease can manifest with pain that radiates to the shoulder or radicular neurologic findings in the arm; however, the first priority in this case is to rule out a superior pulmonary sulcus tumor.

E) CORRECT:

In a patient with a significant history of cigarette smoking, the presence of shoulder pain with muscle wasting in the ipsilateral distal extremity and a normal shoulder examination should suggest the possibility of an upper thoracic tumor compressing or invading the brachial plexus. These tumors, called superior pulmonary sulcus or Pancoast tumors, are typically due to non-small-cell lung cancers. The pain that patients experience is due to invasion of the tumor into the brachial plexus or through extension of the tumor into the parietal pleura, ribs, or vertebra. These tumors can also invade the sympathetic chain and inferior cervical ganglion and cause Horner syndrome. The most appropriate next step is to obtain a chest radiograph.

Key learning point: Shoulder pain and wasting of the small muscles of the hand in a patient with a long history of cigarette smoking should prompt evaluation for superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast tumor) with a chest radiograph.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A heterogeneous mass-like opacity (red overlay) in the right apex extends to a thickened irregular pleural surface (blue overlay). Other vague areas of soft tissue density are also present in the right apex (green overlay), and the posterior cortices of the right 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs (indicated by white dashed outlines) are not fully visualized as a result of tumor invasion.

The findings are consistent with a Pancoast tumor with chest wall extension.

questions.text: You are seeing a 65-year-old woman with hypertension, insulin-requiring diabetes mellitus, end-stage kidney disease, and a history of cigarette smoking who presents with new-onset right shoulder pain and right hand weakness that have progressed over the past 6 weeks. She has also experienced a 7-kg weight loss over the past 4 months. On examination, she has right-sided ptosis with a pinpoint right pupil, as well as muscle atrophy, weakness, and numbness in the fourth and fifth fingers of her right hand. Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arm weakness and numbness in the fingers is more consistent with a dermatomal distribution than with a brainstem lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis leads to renal insufficiency and can cause sensorimotor neuropathy but is not associated with the development of Horner syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Although myasthenia gravis can cause ptosis and muscle weakness, it is not associated with miosis (a component of Horner syndrome).

D) CORRECT:

Tumors of the superior pulmonary sulcus, also called Pancoast tumors, can cause a classic presentation by compressing against nerve structures as they pass through or near the thoracic inlet. Compression of the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots can cause pain and neurologic compromise of those nerves. In addition, interruption of the sympathetic nerve chain running to the head can result in Horner syndrome, which is characterized by unilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis. Treatment of superior pulmonary sulcus tumors involves multidisciplinary care coordinated among a thoracic surgeon, a radiation oncologist, and a medical oncologist.

Key learning point: The gradual development of arm weakness and Horner syndrome in an older patient with a history of cigarette smoking is most indicative of a diagnosis of a superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Although carotid artery dissection could progress to stroke and subsequently cause arm weakness, this event would likely occur more acutely than the gradual development of Horner syndrome.
questions.hint: Ipsilateral miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis indicate Horner syndrome, a constellation of symptoms secondary to compression of the cervical sympathetic ganglion.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He reports that climbing the stairs becomes easier after he has exercised. He has also experienced a 4.6-kg weight loss over the past 6 months. He has a 35-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On examination, he has dry mucous membranes. His pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Muscle strength in the proximal lower extremities is initially 3/5 but increases to 5/5 after repeated muscle tapping. His Achilles reflex is 1+. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) may cause lower limb muscle weakness. However, symptoms typically worsen throughout the day and with exercise as opposed to this patient's improvement of symptoms upon repetitive stimulation. MG classically manifests with weakness of the extraocular muscles causing ptosis and/or diplopia, whereas deep tendon reflexes and autonomic functions are unaffected. Moreover, MG is not associated with lung cancer, but with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases.

B) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) manifests with muscle weakness and may rarely be associated with dysautonomia. However, muscle weakness typically is asymmetric and would not improve with exercise, but show a progressive course. Since both upper and lower motor neurons are affected in ALS, additional symptoms such as hyperreflexia, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism may cause proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, it would usually be associated with other symptoms such as weight gain, fatigue, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Weight loss as seen in this patient would be unusual. Hypothyroidism is not associated with lung cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis manifests with proximal muscle weakness. However, symptoms are typically progressive and would not improve with exercise. Although dermatomyositis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer, cutaneous manifestations such as Gottron papules and a heliotrope rash would also be expected. Moreover, dermatomyositis is not associated with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction.

E) CORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small-cell lung cancer in two-thirds of cases, is caused by circulating autoantibodies that block presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels (anti-VGCC antibodies) at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage impairs acetylcholine (ACh) release, which leads to reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes and proximal muscle weakness; the latter improves during exercise as repetitive nerve stimulation increases the amount of ACh in the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS may also develop symptoms of autonomic dysfunction such as a dry mouth, constipation, or impotence.

Key learning point: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is a paraneoplastic disorder, often linked to small-cell lung cancer, characterized by proximal muscle weakness that improves with activity, autonomic symptoms, and reduced or absent deep tendon reflexes.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody
questions.hint: This patient's combination of smoking history, chronic cough, and weight loss is concerning for lung malignancy. Proximal muscle weakness that improves on repeated stimulation combined with hyporeflexia is suggestive of a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: You are seeing a 58-year-old woman who has a 30-pack-year smoking history and continues to smoke daily. She does not take any medications. Review of systems is unremarkable. She had a normal colonoscopy 5 years ago, an unremarkable chest radiograph and mammogram 6 months ago, and a normal Pap test 6 months ago. Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Low-dose helical CT of the chest.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the breasts is not warranted in a patient with a recent normal mammography and no suspicion for genetic susceptibility to breast cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeat colonoscopy and fecal occult-blood testing are not indicated in a patient with a normal colonoscopy within the past 5 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat colonoscopy and fecal occult-blood testing are not indicated in a patient with a normal colonoscopy within the past 5 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Ovarian ultrasound screenings are not proven to reduce cancer mortality.

E) CORRECT:

The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends annual screening for lung cancer in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20-pack-year history of cigarette smoking and either currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. The preferred screening method is low-dose helical CT of the chest rather than a single chest radiograph or annual chest radiography. In one large study, CT-screened patients had a 20% relative reduction in lung cancer-related mortality, compared with unscreened patients.

Key learning point: In patients aged 50 to 80 years who either currently smoke or have a history of heavy smoking (>20 pack-years), lung cancer screening should be conducted using low-dose helical CT of the chest.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to your clinic for evaluation of a pulmonary nodule that was incidentally detected on chest x-ray. She reports no symptoms. She has a 32-year history of smoking one and a half packs of cigarettes daily. Vital signs are normal. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. CT scan of the chest reveals a nodule in the right lung. Which one of the following radiographic findings is the strongest predictor of malignancy in this pulmonary mass?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules can be determined by clinical evaluation and/or predictive modeling and helps guide management and follow-up. Pulmonary nodules with irregular borders (e.g., scalloped, spiculated) arise due to tumor growth along the pulmonary interstitium and carry a high risk of malignancy. Additional features that indicate a high risk of malignancy include upper lobe location and large nodule size (e.g., > 8–10 mm); older age (e.g. > 60 years), heavy nicotine use, and a history of prior cancer (see “Predictors of malignancy risk in patients with SPNs” table). In high-risk nodules > 8 mm (i.e., comprising only high-risk features) a surgical biopsy should be obtained and treatment should be initiated depending on the results. A PET-CT is indicated for patients with intermediate (i.e., both high and low-risk features) or low-risk nodules (i.e., comprising only low-risk features) > 8 mm. Nodules ≤ 8 mm can be followed up with serial CT scans. Surveillance frequency is determined by the patient's malignancy risk and nodule size.

Key learning point: A spiculated border on a pulmonary nodule is the radiographic feature most strongly associated with malignancy.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window)

A spiculated mass (green overlay) is present in the right upper lobe. A small nodule is also visible medial to the mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Although cavitation can be seen in cavitating lung metastasis, this feature is not specific and therefore not used in the assessment of the risk of malignancy. Inflammatory lung conditions such as lung abscess, sarcoidosis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis can also manifest with cavitation. A different finding is a stronger predictor for malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules.

C) INCORRECT:

Nodule size is a criterion used to assess the risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules. A nodule < 8 mm in size is associated with an intermediate or low risk of malignancy, whereas nodule size > 8–10 mm is considered a high-risk feature.

D) INCORRECT:

Nodule location is a criterion used to assess the risk of malignancy in patients with solitary pulmonary nodules; however, location in the lower lobe is associated with a low risk of malignancy. Upper lobe location is a high-risk feature.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcification can be seen in some lung cancers, such as pulmonary carcinoid tumors. However, this feature is generally associated with benign conditions such as benign pulmonary hamartomas, which are characterized by popcorn calcifications with alterations of fat. Calcifications can also be seen in tuberculosis or Histoplasma capsulatum-induced infectious granulomas.
questions.hint: The presence of certain clinical and radiographic features can help determine the risk of malignancy in solitary pulmonary nodules and guide further management.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with facial swelling and neck vein distension that developed over several days. He has a persistent cough and recent weight loss. Physical examination reveals bilateral upper extremity swelling and jugular venous distension. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diuretics would not address the underlying cause of superior vena cava compression and could potentially worsen the patient's condition by reducing intravascular volume without relieving the mechanical obstruction.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of bilateral upper extremity swelling, facial swelling, and jugular venous distension suggests superior vena cava syndrome, which is an extrapulmonary manifestation of lung cancer. Chest imaging is essential to identify a mediastinal mass or lung tumor that may be compressing the superior vena cava and causing impaired venous return from the head, neck, and upper extremities.

C) INCORRECT:

While cardiac causes can produce venous congestion, the bilateral upper extremity involvement and facial swelling pattern suggests mechanical obstruction of venous return rather than cardiac dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids might provide temporary symptom relief but would not address the underlying mechanical compression. The clinical presentation suggests a structural problem requiring identification of the compressive lesion rather than an inflammatory process.

E) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation would be inappropriate without evidence of thrombotic disease and could be harmful if the patient requires urgent intervention for mediastinal compression.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with a 50–pack-year smoking history presents to the ED with progressive weakness, confusion, and nausea for 3 days. She denies chest pain or shortness of breath. Vital signs are BP, 138/82 mm Hg; P, 92; R, 20; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). Laboratory results show sodium 116 mEq/L, potassium 4.2 mEq/L , calcium 10.0 mg/dL, glucose 92 mg/dL, and serum osmolality 260 mOsm/kg H2O. Chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial ED management?

choices.text: Oral salt tablets and fluid restriction
Hypertonic saline infusion with careful monitoring
Normal saline infusion and IV furosemide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salt tablets and fluid restriction are appropriate for mild, chronic SIADH. However, this patient has severe symptomatic hyponatremia (confusion, Na <120), requiring urgent correction with hypertonic saline.

B) INCORRECT:

Although infection is an important cause of altered mental status, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with paraneoplastic SIADH-induced hyponatremia. Antibiotics are not indicated without signs of infection.

C) INCORRECT:

The chest x-ray shows no pleural effusions, making thoracentesis unnecessary. The first priority here should be the correction of electrolyte abnormalities.

D) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient’s presentation is consistent with symptomatic hyponatremia due to SIADH from small cell lung cancer. Severe symptomatic hyponatremia requires cautious administration of 3% hypertonic saline with close neurologic and electrolyte monitoring to prevent osmotic demyelination.

E) INCORRECT:

In SIADH, normal saline can paradoxically worsen hyponatremia, and furosemide is not appropriate for treating severe symptomatic hyponatremia.
